Last year sometime. Why does that matter?" "Because you sound like—" She stops herself. "Like what?" "Like you need to talk to someone. Like you're not okay." "I'm fine. It's not me. It's Emma." "Okay, but—you're not sleeping, you're not taking your meds, you're seeing patterns in your girlfriend's behavior. Doesn't that sound familiar?" It does. It sounds exactly like the beginning of my mom's episodes. The noticing. The cataloging. The certainty that everyone else was wrong. "I'm not having a break," I say. "I didn't say you were. But maybe—maybe you're stressed. Maybe things with Emma have been hard and your brain is trying to make sense of it by creating a narrative." "I'm not creating anything." "I know you think that. I know it feels real. But that's how it works, right? It always feels real." I close my eyes. The stairwell is cold. Someone's cooking fish in one of the apartments, the smell seeping into the hallway. "Just—can you do something for me?" Melissa asks. "Can you call Dr. Harris? Just talk to her. If you're right and it's Emma, fine, but if it's not—" "It's not me." "Alex, I love you. I'm worried about you. Please just call her." "Fine. I'll call her." "Promise?" "I promise." "Okay. Call me back after? Let me know you're okay?" "Yeah. Okay." I hang up and sit on the stairs and put my head in my hands. My sister thinks I'm losing it. Maybe she's right. Maybe I am. Maybe there's nothing wrong with Emma and everything wrong with me and I can't tell the difference. --- When I come back into the apartment, Emma is standing in the living room. Just standing there. Waiting. "You called someone," she says. "I—yeah. My sister." "What did you tell her?" "Nothing. Just checking in." Emma tilts her head. "You told her about me." It's not a question. I don't know how she knows but she knows. "I'm worried about you," I say. "You told her I was different. You told her I was wrong." Her voice is calm. Factual. "What did she say?" "She said—she thinks maybe I'm stressed." "She thinks you're having a break." "She didn't say that." "But that's what she meant." Emma walks to the couch and sits down. "She thinks you're like your mother." The words land like a slap. "Don't." "You can leave if you want," she says quietly. "I'm not keeping you here." "I don't want to leave. I want you back." "What if this is me?" "It's not." "How do you know?" She looks up at me and her eyes are wet. Actual tears. "How do you know what I am?" I sit down on the chair across from her. My hands are shaking so I put them between my knees. "Tell me what's happening. Please." She's quiet for a long time. When she speaks, her voice is small. Younger than she is. "Three weeks ago I woke up and I felt like I was watching myself from outside. Like I was behind glass, watching Emma move around the apartment, make coffee, get dressed. But it wasn't me doing those things. I was just watching." "Why didn't you tell me?" "Because I wasn't upset about it." She wipes her eyes. "I was relieved. Like I'd been waiting for it. Like I'd been so tired of being myself that when I finally wasn't, it felt like rest." I don't know what to say. "Being depressed was exhausting," she continues. "Being anxious was exhausting. Being Emma was exhausting. And then I just—wasn't. And it was easier." "What do you mean you weren't?" "I mean I floated. I watched. I was still there but I wasn't driving anymore. Something else was. Or I was letting something else. I don't know which." "Emma—" "What if I let something in because I wanted to?" She looks at me directly. "What if I opened a door and invited it?" "Invited what?" "I don't know. The quiet. The distance. The not-feeling." She pulls her knees to her chest. "When I watch you sleep, I'm trying to remember why I'm supposed to want to stay. In my body. In this life. With you. I don't mean that cruelly. I just—I don't remember what wanting feels like." The radiator clanks. The upstairs neighbor walks across their floor. The world continues like this conversation is normal. "I love you," I say, because I don't know what else to say. "I know. I think I love you too. But I can't feel it anymore. I can only remember that I used to." --- We don't talk the rest of the day. We move around each other like roommates, like strangers. She makes dinner. I do the dishes. We sit on the couch with our phones. Everything normal. Everything wrong. At night we get into bed. Neither of us pretends to sleep. We just lie there in the darkness, both awake, both aware the other is awake. At some point I actually do fall asleep. My body just gives up, shuts down despite everything. I'm dreaming. Cold water, dark water, something pulling me down. My lungs burning. The surface getting farther away. I try to swim but I'm so heavy, so tired, and the thing pulling me has so many hands, so many— I wake up choking. Emma's hand is on my throat. Not squeezing. Just resting there, light pressure, her palm against my windpipe. Her hand is ice cold. Her eyes are open. She's staring at me. Her face is blank, empty, like no one's home. "Emma," I whisper. She doesn't respond. Just stares. Her hand doesn't move. "Emma, you're—" Her hand lifts slowly. She looks at it like she's surprised to see it, like it's not connected to her body. Then she looks at me. "I was dreaming," she says. Her voice is flat. "I didn't know I was doing that." She rolls over, turns away from me. I lie there with my hand on my throat, feeling my pulse hammer against my palm, feeling where her cold fingers were. I don't sleep again that night.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates sophisticated psychological horror writing that skillfully maintains ambiguity between supernatural possession and mental health breakdown. The author executes their planned chapter structure with precision, delivering all the key beats: Alex's call to his sister, the resulting self-doubt, and the crucial conversation with Emma about her experience. The character work is particularly strong. Alex's conversation with Melissa feels authentically painful - his desperation to be believed clashing with her well-meaning but dismissive concern perfectly captures the isolation of experiencing something others can't see. The sister's responses ring true to someone dealing with a family member who has mental health vulnerabilities. Alex's internal conflict about whether he's experiencing a breakdown like his mother is psychologically convincing. Emma's monologue about her dissociative experience is the chapter's strongest element. Her description of "watching herself from outside" and feeling "relieved" to not be driving anymore provides a chilling explanation that works both as possession narrative and depression metaphor. The line "When I watch you sleep, I'm trying to remember why I'm supposed to want to stay" is genuinely haunting and emotionally devastating. The dialogue throughout feels natural and serves the story effectively. The conversations don't feel like exposition dumps but rather like real people struggling to communicate about something ineffable. The prose is clean and direct, avoiding purple language while maintaining atmospheric tension. The chapter's final scene - Emma's hand on Alex's throat - is genuinely disturbing and expertly executed. The detail of her cold hand and blank expression maintains the ambiguity while delivering visceral horror. Minor weaknesses include some moments where the writing tips slightly toward telling rather than showing, particularly in transitions between scenes. The pacing occasionally feels rushed in moving between emotional beats. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece of horror writing that successfully balances psychological realism with supernatural dread. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: The Threshold I stop going to work. I tell them I have the flu. Mark texts asking if I need anything. I don't respond. Emma still goes. Or says she does. She leaves at nine, comes back at five-thirty, like clockwork. But her bag is always in the same position when she returns. Her clothes aren't wrinkled from sitting. Her shoes aren't scuffed from walking. I think she's just leaving the building and coming back. I think she's pretending. Or I'm pretending. I don't know which of us is pretending anymore. --- I haven't showered in three days. Or four. The bathroom mirror shows someone I don't recognize. Beard coming in patchy. Eyes sunken. The skin around my fingernails is raw and bleeding from picking. Emma looks perfect. Her skin is smooth, pale, unmarked. Her hair falls in clean lines. She doesn't have the texture of someone living—no oil, no blemishes, no sleep in her eyes. Like a photograph of a person. She sits on the couch and I sit in the chair and we don't speak and the hours pass like sludge. --- "You need to eat," Emma says. She's put a plate in front of me. Pasta. Red sauce. I don't remember her making it. "I'm not hungry." "You haven't eaten today." "How do you know?" She doesn't answer. Just stands there watching me with that blank face. I pick up the fork. The pasta tastes like nothing. I chew eighteen times and swallow and take another bite because she's watching and I don't know what happens if I don't eat. I don't know what she is when I'm not doing what I'm supposed to do. --- Night. We're in bed. Both lying on our backs, staring at the ceiling. Not touching. The space between us is charged with something I don't have a name for. "Do you remember when we met?" I ask. "Yes." "Tell me." "Sophie's birthday party. That bar in Brooklyn with the good happy hour." "What was I wearing?" Pause. "A blue shirt. Button-down." "What did we talk about?" Longer pause. "I don't remember." "We talked about podcasts. You said you only listened to murder ones. I said I listened to too many and it made me paranoid. You laughed and said paranoia was healthy in small doses." "Okay." "Do you remember saying that?" "No." "Do you remember laughing?" "I remember that I did. I don't remember how it felt." I roll onto my side to look at her. She's still staring at the ceiling. "What happened to you?" "I don't know." "Yes you do." She finally turns her head. In the darkness her eyes catch some light I can't identify, reflect it back at me. "I got tired. I was so tired of being her. Being me. And then something offered to take over and I said yes." "What something?" "The quiet. The empty. The space between thoughts." She blinks slowly. "It wanted to know what it was like. To be solid. To have edges. I wanted to know what it was like to not have them. We traded." My heart is pounding. "That's not real. That's not—that doesn't happen." "Doesn't it?" She sits up slowly, that too-smooth movement. "You've been watching me for weeks. You know something is different. You know I'm not lying." "You're sick. You're dissociating or you're having a psychotic break or—" "Or something is living in my body and I let it because I wanted to disappear." Her voice is calm. Matter-of-fact. "Does it matter which?" "Yes. It matters. One means we can get help. One means—" "Means what, Alex? That you were right? That there are things in the world you don't understand?" She tilts her head. "You want it to be possession. You want it to be something outside of me because if it's me, if I chose this, then you have to accept that I wanted to leave you." "That's not—" "I couldn't do it any other way. I couldn't break up with you. I couldn't hurt you like that. So I disappeared from the inside. I let something else have this body because I didn't want it anymore." I'm shaking. "I don't believe you." "Yes you do." She reaches out and touches my face. Her hand is so cold it burns. "You've known for weeks. You just didn't want to say it." --- I get up. Walk to the living room. She follows me. "What do you want from me?" My voice breaks. "Why are you telling me this?" "Because you asked." "Fuck you. That's not—" I turn to face her. "If you're Emma, if any part of you is still Emma, you have to fight this. You have to try." "Why?" "Because I love you." She looks at me with those empty eyes. "I know. She loved you too. But love wasn't enough to make her want to stay." I grab her shoulders. Shake her. "Stop talking about yourself like you're someone else. Stop pretending you're gone. You're right here. You're right fucking here." She doesn't resist. Just lets me shake her like a doll. When I stop, she says quietly, "The Emma you want is gone. I'm what's left. You can accept that or you can keep torturing yourself, but you can't change it." I let go. Step back. "I'm sorry," she says, and for just a moment there's something in her voice. Something that sounds like her. "I'm sorry I'm not strong enough to be what you need." --- She goes back to the bedroom. I hear the door close. I sit on the couch and put my head in my hands and I think about my options. I could call 911. Tell them my girlfriend is having a mental health crisis. They'd take her to the hospital. They'd evaluate her. Put her on a seventy-two hour hold maybe. Medication. Therapy. She'd get help. Or I'm the one who's sick. I'm the one cataloging impossible things, seeing patterns that don't exist, convinced my girlfriend is possessed. They'd take one look at my family history, my lack of sleep, my stopped medication, and they'd know. I could pack a bag. Leave right now. Get in my car and drive to Melissa's in Denver. Save myself. Let Emma figure out her own shit, let whatever this is burn itself out without me. But if I leave and she's really sick, really in danger, and something happens— Or: I could accept it. Accept that she's different now. That the Emma I knew is gone and this is what remains. I could learn to live with this stranger who wears her face. People do that. People stay in relationships that have transformed into something unrecognizable. They call it commitment. Or: nothing is wrong. Emma is fine and I'm losing my mind and none of this is real and tomorrow I'll wake up and realize I've been hallucinating for weeks. I don't know which option is true. I don't know which option is worse. --- I must fall asleep on the couch because I wake to sunlight through the window and my neck is stiff and my mouth tastes like metal. Emma is standing at the window. Still as a statue. The light comes through her white t-shirt and I can see the outline of her body and she looks real, solid, human. "Emma." She doesn't turn. "Emma, please." Slowly, she looks back at me over her shoulder. Her face is expressionless. "I need to know if you're still in there," I say. "I need to know if I'm fighting for something real."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a significant escalation in the psychological horror narrative, bringing the central mystery to a potential climax through direct confrontation and revelation. The writing maintains the claustrophobic atmosphere established in earlier chapters while pushing the ambiguity about Emma's condition to its breaking point. The characterization remains strong and consistent with the established profiles. Alex's deterioration is effectively portrayed through concrete details - his unwashed state, bleeding cuticles, and paranoid observations about Emma's unchanged bag and unwrinkled clothes. His controlling nature manifests in his desperate need for definitive answers, refusing to accept ambiguity even when Emma offers it. Emma's cold, analytical responses align perfectly with the "during" phase described in her profile, while her revelation about wanting to "disappear from the inside" connects meaningfully to her established depression and desire to escape herself. The dialogue carries significant emotional weight and feels naturalistic. Emma's explanation - "I got tired of being her. Being me. And then something offered to take over and I said yes" - is devastating in its simplicity while maintaining the story's central ambiguity about whether this is supernatural possession or psychological breakdown. The conversation avoids exposition dumps and instead reveals character through conflict. The chapter effectively builds tension through pacing and structure. The fragmented sections separated by dashes create a sense of disjointed time and deteriorating mental state. The progression from mundane observations about Emma's unchanged routine to the climactic bedroom conversation feels earned. However, the chapter risks undermining some of the story's carefully maintained ambiguity. Emma's explanation, while emotionally resonant, edges toward making the supernatural interpretation too explicit. The line "something is living in my body and I let it" moves away from the planned genuine uncertainty about what's happening. Additionally, some dialogue moments like "You want it to be possession" feel slightly forced in their psychological insight. The writing occasionally relies on repetitive sentence structures ("I think she's just leaving... I think she's pretending. Or I'm pretending") which, while fitting Alex's obsessive mental state, can become monotonous. The emotional beats are well-earned overall, though some moments approach melodrama, particularly in the physical confrontation where Alex shakes Emma. The chapter successfully maintains the intimate, claustrophobic tone while advancing the plot toward what feels like an inevitable breaking point. The ending leaves Alex (and readers) with impossible choices, each carrying different implications about reality and responsibility. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: What Remains She turns away from the window. Looks at me with eyes that might be hers. "I don't know," she says. --- Time passes. Days or weeks. The calendar on my phone says November but that doesn't mean anything. Emma still goes to work. I start going back too. Mark doesn't ask questions anymore, just glances at me sometimes with something like concern or fear. I do my job. I close tickets. I monitor systems for threats. I'm good at finding patterns. At home, we've developed routines. Emma sleeps in the bed. I sleep on the couch. We agreed to this without discussing it. One night I just didn't come to bed and she didn't ask why and now that's how it is. She still cooks. I still do dishes. We still exist in the same space. She doesn't watch me sleep anymore. Or I don't catch her. I don't know which. --- Dr. Harris called me back after I left a voicemail at two in the morning. I went to see her. Sat in her office with the plants and the soft lighting and told her everything. She listened. Took notes. Asked careful questions. "Have you considered that Emma might be experiencing a dissociative episode?" she asked. "Yes." "And that your response—the monitoring, the cataloging—might be exacerbating it?" "Yes." "Have you considered that you might be experiencing a break from reality?" "Every day." She prescribed me something. I got it filled. The bottle sits on the counter. I look at it every morning and don't take it because if I take it and the wrongness goes away, that means it was never real. And if it was never real, that means I did this to Emma. Drove her away with my paranoia, my controlling, my pattern-seeking brain. And if I take it and the wrongness doesn't go away, that means the pills don't work. Or it means it's real. Or it means we're both sick. The bottle sits there. A Schrödinger's cure. --- Sometimes Emma is almost herself. Last Tuesday she made a joke about her boss. A real joke, with timing, with inflection. I laughed and she smiled and for five minutes we were just two people who lived together. Yesterday she put her hand on my shoulder as she passed behind the couch. Just a brief touch, casual, the way she used to. My throat closed up. I didn't say anything. This morning she was crying in the bathroom. Real tears, real shaking sobs. I stood outside the door. "Emma? Can I help?" "No." Her voice was thick, human, breaking. "I just need a minute." When she came out, her eyes were red. She looked at me and something in her face was raw and present and terrified. "I don't know what's happening to me," she whispered. I reached for her and she let me hold her and she felt warm, finally warm, and she shook against me and I thought this is it, she's coming back, she's fighting her way back. Then she went still. The shaking stopped. She pulled away and her face was smooth again, empty again. "I'm fine," she said. "I'm going to be late for work." She left. I stood in the hallway and tried to remember if that moment was real. --- Sophie called Emma last week. I heard Emma's side of the conversation from the other room. "I'm good. No, really, I'm good. Work is fine. Alex is fine. We're fine." Her voice had all the right inflections. All the right warmth. She laughed at something Sophie said. She asked about Sophie's boyfriend. She sounded exactly like Emma. When she hung up, she sat on the couch and stared at her phone. "That was good," I said. "You sounded like yourself." "I was pretending," she said flatly. "I'm always pretending now. I don't know how to stop." --- I think about leaving every day. I pack a bag in my head. Clothes, laptop, important documents. I plan the conversation. Emma, I can't do this anymore. Emma, I love you but this is killing me. Emma, I don't know what you are. But then it's night and she's across the room and I'm on the couch and we're both pretending to look at our phones and I think: where would I go? What would change? The wrongness lives in me now too. I've been watching for it so long I don't know how to stop. I'd carry it with me. I'd find it in whoever came next, in whatever life I built, because now I know what to look for. I know how to see the performance, the pretending, the space between what people are and what they show. Emma didn't do that to me. I've always been this way. She just made it visible. --- Two nights ago I woke on the couch to find her standing over me. My heart seized but I didn't move. Didn't speak. She stood there for a long time. Just looking. Then she sat down on the edge of the couch. Slowly, carefully, like she was asking permission. I still didn't move. She put her hand on my chest. Over my heart. Her palm was cold but not as cold as before. Or I've gotten used to it. "I can feel it," she said quietly. "The beating. I'd forgotten what that felt like." "What what felt like?" "Being close to something alive." We stayed like that. Her hand on my chest. Me lying still. The radiator clanking. The upstairs neighbor coughing through the ceiling. "Are you still in there?" I asked. "Is any of you still in there?" She didn't answer for a long time. Then: "I don't know what I am anymore. But I'm here. Whatever that means. I'm still here." It wasn't enough. It should have been enough. She went back to the bedroom. I lay awake until morning. --- Today is Thursday. I know because the garbage needs to go out. Emma is at the window again, watching the nothing outside. I'm on the couch with my laptop, not working. This is our life now. This is what remains. I don't know if she's possessed or sick or just done with being who she was. I don't know if I'm documenting reality or creating it. I don't know if love is enough or if it was ever the right thing. What I know: She's here. I'm here. We're both pretending and both refusing to leave. What I know: Sometimes when she looks at me, I see something that might be her or might be something wearing her or might be who she actually is when she's not performing. What I know: I catch her staring at me sometimes. Just staring. And when our eyes meet, she doesn't look away anymore. Just holds my gaze with those dark, unreadable eyes. And I stare back. We're watching each other now. Both of us. Waiting to see who breaks first. Waiting to see what happens when we finally stop pretending we don't know what this is. The apartment is cold. The radiator clanks. Emma stands at the window and I sit on the couch and outside the city continues, indifferent to what's happening in this small space on the fourth floor. We'll learn to live with the uncertainty. We have to. We don't have any other choice.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter effectively concludes the possession horror story while maintaining the ambiguity that has been the work's central strength. The writing demonstrates sophisticated restraint, focusing on psychological realism and relationship dynamics rather than supernatural spectacle. The characterization remains nuanced throughout. Alex's internal conflict between his controlling tendencies and genuine love for Emma feels authentic and complex. His recognition that "The wrongness lives in me now too" shows meaningful self-awareness without undermining the horror elements. Emma's moments of breakthrough - the crying in the bathroom, her confession about pretending - create genuine emotional stakes while preserving uncertainty about her condition. The prose style is controlled and effective, avoiding purple language while maintaining atmospheric tension. Specific details like the unopened pill bottle serving as a "Schrödinger's cure" work both literally and symbolically without feeling forced. The writing captures the claustrophobic domesticity that makes this horror particularly unsettling. The chapter successfully balances showing and telling, with concrete behavioral observations (Emma's hand placement, the temperature of her touch) carrying more weight than exposition. The dialogue feels natural and serves character development, particularly Emma's line "I don't know what I am anymore. But I'm here." The ending resists resolution while providing emotional closure, which aligns perfectly with the story's commitment to ambiguity. The final image of mutual watching inverts the original dynamic effectively. The pacing allows moments to breathe without losing momentum. Some minor weaknesses include occasional repetitive phrasing and a few moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly overwrought, but these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is a skillfully crafted psychological horror story that effectively builds tension through an unreliable narrator documenting his girlfriend's increasingly disturbing behavior. The story succeeds primarily through its ambiguity - we're never certain whether Emma is genuinely possessed/changed or whether Alex is experiencing a psychological breakdown stemming from his family history of mental illness. The characterization is strong, particularly Alex's voice as an obsessive, pattern-seeking narrator whose controlling tendencies are revealed gradually. His background in tech support (monitoring systems for threats) cleverly parallels his compulsive documentation of Emma's behavior. Emma herself is portrayed with nuance - whether interpreted as possessed or simply someone escaping depression through dissociation, her responses feel authentic. The story maintains excellent pacing, escalating from minor oddities (not blinking enough, cold skin) to more unsettling behaviors (watching him sleep, mechanical movements) to the final confrontation. The worldbuilding is grounded and realistic, using mundane details (apartment layout, work routines, relationship dynamics) to anchor the supernatural elements. However, the piece has some weaknesses. Certain details become repetitive (the 18 chews, 12-second breathing pattern) in a way that feels mechanical rather than atmospheric. Some moments lean toward telling rather than showing, particularly in Alex's internal analysis of his situation. The dialogue, while generally natural, occasionally becomes too expository during crucial revelations. The story's greatest strength lies in its sustained ambiguity and the way it explores themes of control, mental illness, and the unknowability of other people. The ending's irresolution works for the horror genre, leaving readers uncertain about the truth while suggesting both characters are trapped in their respective prisons of perception. The prose is clean and effective without being overly stylized. The horror emerges from psychological realism rather than supernatural spectacle, making it more unsettling. The story faithfully follows the prompt, expanding the initial premise into a complex exploration of relationship dynamics and psychological horror. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Pacing: 17 World Building: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 81.5/100
+ Pulp Revenge Tale — Babysitter's Payback (Chapter Avg: 80.0 | Final: 79.3)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Pulp Revenge Tale Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: They fucked with the wrong babysitter.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Pulp Revenge Tale Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: They fucked with the wrong babysitter. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming ## Character Concepts **Babysitter Options:** - College student working part-time, secretly trained in martial arts/self-defense - Ex-military/law enforcement trying to live a quiet life - Young person with a mysterious past, running from something - Sweet-seeming teenager who's actually incredibly resourceful and clever - Professional nanny with skills acquired from previous dangerous job (bodyguard, intelligence agent) - Street-smart hustler who babysits as cover for other activities - Ordinary person pushed to extraordinary limits **Antagonists:** - Home invasion crew who picked the wrong house - Human traffickers who target the children - Organized crime family connected to one parent - Corrupt cops involved in illegal activities - Wealthy sadists playing a "game" - Drug dealers seeking revenge on the parents - Kidnappers holding children for ransom ## Plot Direction Options **Option 1: Home Invasion** - Babysitter and kids targeted during routine night - Multiple intruders expecting easy marks - Becomes cat-and-mouse through the house - Babysitter uses knowledge of home layout and improvised weapons - Escalates as we learn why they're really there **Option 2: Conspiracy Uncovered** - Babysitter accidentally discovers parents' secret criminal activity - Must protect kids from parents' enemies - Goes on the run with children - Turns hunter instead of hunted - Confronts the conspiracy **Option 3: Kidnapping Gone Wrong** - Professional kidnapping attempt - Babysitter prevents initial grab - Hunters become hunted - Tracks them back to their organization - Dismantles operation piece by piece **Option 4: Undercover** - Babysitter is actually undercover protection - Real identity unknown to family - Threat materializes as expected - Goes from covert to overt protection - Reveals true capabilities ## Tone Options - Hard-boiled noir with internal monologue - Grindhouse exploitation style with over-the-top action - Taut thriller with psychological elements - Dark comedy with absurdist violence - Serious character study with brutal realism - Genre-savvy and self-aware pulp ## Story Beat Structures **Structure A - Escalating Threat:** 1. Normal evening establishing character 2. Threat arrives/is discovered 3. First confrontation - babysitter shows capability 4. Situation escalates/reinforcements arrive 5. Backstory revealed while fighting 6. Major setback/injury/capture 7. Turning tables/final preparation 8. Climactic revenge/resolution **Structure B - Hunter Becomes Hunted:** 1. Establish babysitter and routine 2. Attack happens - kids secured 3. Pursuing the attackers 4. First revenge - gathering information 5. Going up the chain 6. Major confrontation with lieutenant 7. Final approach to boss 8. Showdown and aftermath **Structure C - Mystery to Action:** 1-2. Slow build - something's wrong 3. Revelation of true threat 4-5. Protection and evasion 6-7. Counter-offensive 8. Resolution ## Pacing Considerations for 8 Chapters - Chapter 1: Setup (1000 words to establish normalcy and character) - Chapters 2-3: Inciting incident and immediate response (2000 words) - Chapters 4-6: Rising action and complications (3000 words) - Chapter 7: Climax (1000 words) - Chapter 8: Resolution (1000 words) ## Setting Ideas - Isolated suburban home - Wealthy estate with security systems - Urban apartment building - Rural farmhouse - Gated community - Penthouse - Safe house that isn't safe # Reflection **What Works:** The home invasion angle (Option 1) provides the most natural container for an 8-chapter structure. It allows for immediate tension while providing opportunities for flashbacks and character development during lulls in action. The confined setting also helps manage scope for 8000 words. A protagonist with hidden skills (ex-military, ex-agent, or someone with a mysterious past) gives us the most satisfying payoff for "fucked with the wrong babysitter." The contrast between expectations (helpless young caregiver) and reality (capable warrior) is inherently pulpy and satisfying. For tone, leaning into self-aware pulp with hard-boiled elements would work best. Too serious and it becomes a different genre; too comedic and the stakes disappear. The sweet spot is taking the action seriously while acknowledging the genre we're playing in through style and voice. **Pacing Concerns:** Eight chapters is actually quite generous for a home invasion story. The risk is either: a) padding the middle with repetitive action, or b) rushing through what should be tense moments. The solution might be: - Use 2 chapters for setup to really establish character - Make the invasion multi-staged (initial intrusion, regrouping, reinforcements) - Include pursuit/counter-attack beyond the house - Reveal why they came and what they wanted **What Needs Development:** The antagonists need proper motivation beyond generic "bad guys." Options: - They're after something in the house (data, money, evidence) - The parents set this up (insurance fraud, getting rid of kids) - Wrong house, but they can't back out now - Personal vendetta against the babysitter they didn't know would be there The children's role needs consideration. Too involved and it strains credibility; too absent and we lose emotional stakes. Perhaps: babysitter secures them early, they're the reason she can't just escape, maybe one helps in a small but crucial way. **Character Arc:** For a satisfying 8000-word arc, the babysitter should have an internal journey. Possible arcs: - Running from violence, forced to embrace it again - Thinks she's ordinary, discovers capability - Believes in rules/law, must break them - Isolated loner, fights for connection to kids - Guilty over past failure, gets redemption **Structural Decision Points:** The story needs a major turning point around chapter 4-5. Options: - Babysitter is captured/injured but escapes - Kids are taken despite her efforts - Reveals her true identity/past - Discovers the real reason for the attack - Reinforcements arrive for villains OR protagonist The ending needs to deliver on "revenge." This isn't just survival - the protagonist needs to actively punish the antagonists. This means shifting from defensive to offensive, probably around chapter 6. **Best Combination:** After reflection, I'm leaning toward: - **Protagonist:** Young woman (early 20s) babysitting to pay bills, with military background (veteran, discharged after incident) - **Antagonists:** Professional crew after data/evidence in the house, connected to organized crime - **Setup:** Two chapters establishing her character and the family - **Inciting incident:** End of chapter 2 - **Escalation:** Chapters 3-5, defensive actions - **Turn:** Chapter 5-6, she goes on offense - **Climax:** Chapter 7 - **Resolution:** Chapter 8 This structure allows for character depth, justified competence, escalating stakes, and a proper revenge arc.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Premise:** A young military veteran working as a babysitter becomes the last line of defense when a professional criminal crew invades the home she's watching. What begins as a desperate attempt to protect two children escalates into a calculated revenge mission when she discovers why they really came—and what they're willing to do. **Protagonist:** Maya Torres, 23, former Army MP who took an early discharge after a traumatic incident. She's been drifting since leaving the service, working cash jobs including babysitting. She's competent and trained but psychologically scarred, avoiding violence and trying to convince herself she's just a normal civilian now. The invasion forces her to confront what she's capable of and whether she can live with it. **Antagonists:** A four-person crew led by Kasper, a cold professional retrieval specialist. They're after an encrypted drive containing evidence that will expose their employer—a mid-level crime boss whose daughter's family (the parents Maya babysits for) accidentally came into possession of it. They expected to walk into an empty house or deal with a scared teenage babysitter. They're competent but not military-level, and their underestimation proves fatal. **Tone & Style:** - Hard-boiled pulp with tight, punchy prose - Present tense for immediacy during action; past tense for reflective moments - Internal monologue revealing Maya's tactical thinking and psychological state - Violence is brutal and consequential, not cartoonish - Self-aware genre play without breaking the fourth wall - Noir-influenced: moral ambiguity, isolation, competence under pressure **Structural Approach:** - Chapters 1-2: Slow burn establishment of normalcy and character, ending with home invasion - Chapters 3-4: Defensive actions, protecting the children, learning what the crew wants - Chapter 5: Turning point—children are secured, Maya's military past revealed, she shifts to offense - Chapters 6-7: Methodical hunting and elimination of crew members, escalating to leader - Chapter 8: Final confrontation with Kasper and aftermath, moral reckoning **Aiming For:** - Subversion of "helpless victim" tropes - Earned competence (military background justifies skills) - Emotional stakes through the children without making them unrealistically involved - Satisfying revenge that feels like justice, not sadism - Character arc: from running from her past to accepting who she is - Lean, efficient prose that moves quickly - Creative use of domestic environment as tactical space **Avoiding:** - Cartoonish invincibility (she gets hurt, makes mistakes) - Exposition dumps (reveal background through action and brief flashbacks) - Repetitive action beats (each confrontation should be distinct) - Helpless children as mere props (they're people, even if protected) - Torture porn or excessive cruelty - Unearned skills or deus ex machina solutions - Moral simplicity (she should question what she's doing) # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1: "The Gig" (~1000 words) **Setup and normalcy** Maya arrives at the Hendersons' upscale suburban home for another routine Friday night babysitting job. Establish her character through small details: the way she clocks exits and sight lines habitually, her discomfort with the wealth around her, her genuine warmth with the kids (Emma, 8, and Josh, 5). The parents leave for a charity gala. Maya goes through the evening routine—dinner, playtime, bedtime stories. Brief hints at her past: military bearing she tries to soften, hypervigilance she can't fully suppress, medication bottles she carries. She's trying so hard to be normal. Ends with kids asleep, Maya settling on the couch with her phone, when she notices a vehicle passing the house twice. Her instincts activate. **Key beats:** - Establish Maya's character and skills subtly - Make the children real and likeable - Show the house layout for later tactical use - End with first sign of threat ## Chapter 2: "Breach" (~1000 words) **Inciting incident** Maya investigates the suspicious vehicle, trying to convince herself she's being paranoid. She's not. She catches sight of figures approaching the house from multiple angles—this is coordinated. Her training kicks in. She has maybe two minutes. Quick decisions: gets the kids from their beds without fully waking them, hides them in the reinforced panic room she'd noticed earlier (basement wine cellar with heavy door). Tells Emma if she doesn't come back in two hours, press the emergency button. Returns upstairs just as the power cuts. The crew enters—she watches from concealment as Kasper and three others spread through the house. They're looking for something, tossing rooms. She realizes they don't know she's here yet. She has to keep it that way until she understands what they want. But when one crew member heads toward the basement, she has no choice. First confrontation: she takes him down quietly, violently. The others know someone's here now. **Key beats:** - Children secured early (remove them as immediate threat) - Establish antagonists as competent professionals - Maya's first violent action crosses a threshold - Situation locked in—home invasion underway ## Chapter 3: "Rules of Engagement" (~1000 words) **First blood** The house becomes a battlefield. Maya uses her knowledge of the layout, darkness, and surprise. She's outnumbered but has advantages: they're confused, she's motivated, and she knows where everything is. Cat-and-mouse through rooms. She takes out a second crew member (the team's tech guy) using improvised weapons—kitchen knife, heavy bookend. Not clean kills; desperate, messy fights. She's injured (cut across her ribs, bruised). Kasper and his remaining partner, Yev, regroup. Through overheard conversation, she learns they're after "the drive" and they're on a clock—employer is expecting confirmation within the hour. They realize they're dealing with someone trained. Kasper makes a decision: burn through the house systematically, room by room. They start setting fires. Stakes escalate. **Key beats:** - Two antagonists eliminated (four down to two) - Maya is hurt—she's not invincible - Reveal what they're after (adds mystery) - Fire raises stakes (time pressure, danger to kids below) ## Chapter 4: "What They Came For" (~1000 words) **Information and escalation** The fire forces Maya to adapt. She triggers the sprinkler system (buying time) and uses the chaos to her advantage. Brief flashback during a quiet moment: we see glimpses of her military service and why she left (incident involving civilian casualties, her failure to prevent violence). She's terrified she's becoming that person again. She finds what the crew was searching for—an encrypted thumb drive hidden in Mr. Henderson's study. She doesn't know what's on it, but it's clearly worth killing for. Kasper calls his employer, and Maya overhears enough to understand: the Hendersons witnessed something they shouldn't have, someone gave them evidence, and now there's a kill order—on the whole family, including the children. This isn't just robbery. They came to murder everyone and make it look like a home invasion gone wrong. The rage this ignites in Maya is cold and focused. The game changes. **Key beats:** - Reveal the true stakes (kill order on children) - Maya finds the MacGuffin - Flashback provides character depth - Psychological shift: from defense to offense ## Chapter 5: "The Professional" (~1000 words) **Turning point** Maya secures the drive and checks on the kids (they're terrified but safe). This is the pivotal moment. She could call the police, hole up, wait for help. But she knows how this works: even if these men are caught, the employer walks free and sends others. The kids will never be safe. She makes a choice—she's going to end this tonight, permanently. She stops running and starts hunting. Takes stock of her resources: Kasper and Yev have guns, but so does she now (taken from fallen crew members). She has tactical advantages. Short internal monologue: she's done trying to be someone she's not. She knows what she is—a weapon pointed at bad people. She embraces it. The tone shifts. Methodical preparation: she rigs traps, creates chokepoints, uses the house itself against them. Lures Yev into an ambush. The kill is calculated, efficient. Kasper realizes he's now alone, hunted in an unfamiliar space by someone more dangerous than him. **Key beats:** - Maya's psychological transformation complete - Shift from reactive to proactive - Third antagonist eliminated (only Kasper remains) - Embrace of her true nature/skills ## Chapter 6: "Extraction" (~1000 words) **The hunt** Kasper is a professional and understands when a job is blown. He attempts to extract: calls for backup, tries to leave. But Maya has disabled his vehicle and blocked exits. He's trapped. The hunter-hunted dynamic is fully reversed. Maya uses psychological warfare—speaks to him from concealment, lets him know she has the drive, explains exactly what she's going to do. Kasper tries to negotiate, then threaten (backup is coming, his employer is powerful, she's just one person). Maya doesn't care. Tactical cat-and-mouse. Kasper gets desperate, tries to use the fire (reigniting it) or find the panic room (thinking kids are leverage). Each attempt fails. Maya is always a step ahead. Brief moment where Kasper sees her clearly—recognizes military training, realizes the scope of his mistake. He makes one last play: claims he'll give up his employer, walk away, pretend this never happened. Her response is silence and action. **Key beats:** - Reversal complete: antagonist is prey - Psychological warfare - Kasper's desperation and recognition - Setup for final confrontation ## Chapter 7: "Wrong Babysitter" (~1000 words) **Climax** Final confrontation. Kasper, cornered and desperate, makes his last stand. It's brutal and personal—not a gunfight but close-quarters combat in the destroyed living room. Both are injured. Kasper fights with professional desperation; Maya fights with righteous fury. The contrast in their motivations becomes clear: he's a hired gun who took a job, she's protecting children she cares about. During the fight, Kasper makes a final play—tries to reach the panic room, thinking he can leverage the kids. Maya stops him permanently. The kill is definitive and earned. In the aftermath, she stands over his body, injured and exhausted. The house is destroyed. Sirens in the distance—neighbors finally called 911. She retrieves Kasper's phone, finds the employer's contact information. The revenge isn't complete until the person who ordered the hit on children is dealt with. **Key beats:** - Final physical confrontation - Thematic clarity (motivation contrast) - Kasper's death - Setup for true revenge (the employer) ## Chapter 8: "Aftermath" (~1000 words) **Resolution and reckoning** Police and fire arrive. Maya has a story prepared (partial truth: home invasion, she fought back). The kids are found safe. Paramedics treat her injuries. Detective interviews are brief—she's a hero who saved children. The Hendersons return, horrified and grateful. But Maya isn't done. Days later, recovered enough to move: she uses the information from Kasper's phone and the evidence on the drive. She tracks down the employer (mid-level crime boss named Serrano). Not a big confrontation—something quieter and more devastating. She delivers the encrypted drive to the FBI with enough context to destroy him, and she visits him once before his arrest to make sure he knows exactly who ended his empire and why. Final scene: Maya with the kids one last time before the Hendersons move away (witness protection). Emma asks if she's a soldier. Maya answers honestly: "I was. Maybe I still am." She walks away, not back to her old aimless life, but forward to something new—accepting what she is and finding purpose in it. Ends with her taking a call about another job, but this one is different: private security, protecting people who need it. She's found her path. **Key beats:** - Immediate aftermath and official story - True revenge on employer (non-violent but thorough) - Farewell to children (emotional closure) - Maya's character arc complete: acceptance and new purpose - Pulp satisfaction: bad guys destroyed, hero transformed
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# LLM Writing Patterns & Pitfalls (General) ## Common LLM Failure Modes **1. Emotional Safety & Conflict Avoidance** - Tendency to resolve tensions quickly and neatly - Characters apologize and communicate perfectly - Violence is described but not felt - Trauma is acknowledged but not inhabited - Everyone learns lessons and grows symmetrically **2. Structural Predictability** - Three-act structure followed religiously - Beat sheets executed mechanically - Foreshadowing that's too obvious - Payoffs that feel obligatory rather than earned - Chapter endings that always hook in the same way **3. Prose Patterns** - Varied sentence structure to a fault (always: short. Medium length. Then a longer one that flows.) - Metaphors that feel writerly rather than natural - Emotional beats marked explicitly ("She felt angry" vs showing anger) - Overuse of filtering verbs (she noticed, she felt, she saw) - Vocabulary that's impressive but not character-specific **4. Character Flattening** - Protagonists who are too good (even their flaws are noble) - Clear delineation between good and bad - Trauma as backstory flavoring, not ongoing condition - Internal monologue that's too articulate and self-aware - Characters who always make smart decisions (or whose dumb decisions are obviously for plot) **5. Thematic Overexplaining** - Stating the theme explicitly - Having characters realize things too clearly - Tying everything back to a central message - Symbolic elements that announce themselves - Endings that explain what we should take away **6. The "Prestige TV" Problem** - Everything is significant - No random details or loose ends - Every character has an arc - Subversion becomes predictable (expectations reversed because that's clever) - Darkness or grittiness as aesthetic rather than genuine ## How These Might Not Serve This Piece **For a Pulp Revenge Tale specifically:** Pulp thrives on messiness, excess, and raw emotion. It should feel slightly out of control—even if the writer is in control. The original pulps weren't written by people trying to write "well" in a literary sense; they were written fast, for money, with genuine investment in delivering thrills. They have: - Ugly moments that don't serve character growth - Excessive violence that might be cathartic or disturbing (not neatly justified) - Moral ambiguity that isn't resolved - Loose ends and unexplained elements - Protagonist choices driven by emotion, not tactics - Style that prioritizes momentum over polish LLM writing tends toward the controlled, the explained, the balanced. Pulp should feel rawer. # Critique of Current Plan ## Major Issues ### 1. **Too Much Arc, Not Enough Anger** The plan has Maya going on a complete hero's journey: reluctant warrior → accepts herself → finds new purpose. This is *narratively satisfying* but might not be *human*. A real person in this situation might: - Not have clear realizations - End the story more fucked up, not less - Act on rage and adrenaline, not calculated choices - Feel nothing during the violence, then fall apart after - Not find redemption or purpose—just survive and have to live with it The current ending (she becomes private security, finds her path) is wrapping it with a bow. It's the "professional" writing choice. A human writer might be meaner to their protagonist. ### 2. **Kasper Is Too Professional, Not Human Enough** The antagonists are competent professionals who underestimated their target. This is clean. But real criminals are: - Often stupid in specific ways - Cruel beyond necessity - Talkative and boastful - Have personalities, grudges, fears - Might include someone who doesn't want to be there - Could be personally offensive (misogynistic, racist) in ways that make the revenge MORE satisfying Current plan treats them as tactical obstacles. They should be people Maya (and readers) want to see hurt. ### 3. **The Children Are Props** Emma and Josh are established as "real and likeable" then immediately locked in a panic room. They're the stakes but not present. This is the *safe* writing choice—keeps them out of danger, avoids complexity. But realistically: - Kids that age wouldn't stay quiet for hours - Emma (8) might try to help or disobey - The terror they'd feel is real and should bleed into the narrative - Maya might have to be harsh with them in ways she regrets - One of them might see something traumatic - Their presence should complicate things more ### 4. **The Military Background Is Too Clean** "Former Army MP with traumatic incident" is shorthand. It explains competence efficiently. But it's also generic—the kind of backstory an LLM generates because it's versatile and uncontroversial. A human writer might: - Give her a specific, weird skill set (combat medic? drone operator? something unexpected) - Make her background more complicated (dishonorably discharged? AWOL? whistleblower?) - Have her military experience be less directly applicable (she was logistics, not combat—so she's improvising) - Make the trauma specific and intrusive, not just motivational - Or skip military entirely—what if she's just someone who refuses to be a victim? ### 5. **Every Action Is Tactical** The plan describes Maya thinking tactically, using the environment, being methodical. This is the *LLM idea* of how a competent person acts. But real violence is: - Terrifying even when you win - Often instinctive, not planned - Sloppy and desperate - Punctuated by moments of blank thought or panic - Sometimes driven by rage that overrides tactics She should make mistakes. Do things inefficiently because she's furious. Get lucky. Have moments where she freezes or fucks up. ### 6. **The Moral Journey Is Too Neat** Plan has: avoids violence → forced to embrace it → accepts who she is → finds purpose. This is *therapeutic*. It's the kind of arc that says "violence is okay if you're protecting innocents and you accept responsibility." It's morally comfortable. A human writer might leave her: - Disgusted with herself - Aware she enjoyed parts of it (and hating that) - Traumatized in new ways - Uncertain whether she was right - Changed in ways that aren't positive ### 7. **The Employer Endgame Is Too Just** She defeats him non-violently by giving evidence to the FBI, visits to let him know she won. This is... reasonable adult behavior. It's justice-system-approved revenge. Pulp doesn't do that. Pulp would have her: - Kill him too (and maybe it's wrong, excessive, but she does it) - Destroy him in a more personal, cruel way - OR let him go because she's too tired, leaving it unresolved - Face real consequences (she's arrested, or on the run) The current plan is the "responsible" ending that says revenge is okay if you do it legally. That's not pulp. ### 8. **No Genuine Surprises** The plan is logical: setup → invasion → defense → turn → offense → climax → resolution. Every beat follows expectably. A human writer might: - Throw in a genuine WTF moment (one of the parents is involved? A crew member is a kid? Someone unexpected arrives?) - Kill a character we didn't expect - Have the drive be something other than what we think - Take a hard left turn structurally ### 9. **The Prose Intentions Are Vague** "Hard-boiled pulp with tight, punchy prose" and "internal monologue revealing tactical thinking" are *descriptions* of a style, not the style itself. They're what an LLM says when planning because they sound right. A human writer would have: - Specific prose tics in mind (sentence fragments? profanity? particular rhythm?) - A comp title ("write it like early Joe R. Lansdale" or "like a 1970s paperback") - Sample sentences already in their head - A voice choice (first person? close third? style indirect libre?) ### 10. **Everything Means Something** The plan has every element serving the story: the panic room exists so kids can be safe, the fire escalates stakes, the drive is the MacGuffin, etc. This is *efficient* storytelling. Human writing often includes: - Details that go nowhere - Descriptions for atmosphere, not plot - Characters who don't serve clear functions - Moments that are just moments The current plan is too functional. ## Specific Chapter Problems **Chapter 1:** "Brief hints at her past" and "military bearing she tries to soften" is LLM subtlety—the kind that carefully foreshadows. Real opening might just show her being bored, tired, checking her phone, annoyed at rich people shit. **Chapter 2:** Kids being secured immediately is too competent. What if she doesn't know about a panic room? What if she has to improvise and it's not perfect? **Chapter 3:** "Not clean kills; desperate, messy fights" is stated but the plan doesn't really engage with what messy means. How messy? Does she vomit? Shake? Freeze? **Chapter 4:** The flashback to "why she left military (civilian casualties)" is generic tragic backstory. It's the LLM version of depth. **Chapter 5:** "She embraces it" as a turning point is too clear, too empowering. Real people don't have movie moments where they accept themselves. **Chapter 6:** "Maya uses psychological warfare" makes her too cool, too in control. She should be running on fumes and rage. **Chapter 7:** "Righteous fury" vs "professional desperation" as contrast is too thematically neat. **Chapter 8:** Everything about this is tidy. The hero talk with Emma, the new purpose, the "accepting what she is." It's therapy-speak masquerading as pulp. # Brainstorming Human Approaches ## Perspective Shifts **What if it's first person?** - More immediate and raw - Can't hide inside "she thought" constructions - Forces specific voice choices - Limits what we know (can't see antagonists when Maya isn't there) - More pulpy (most hard-boiled is first person) **What if it starts in media res?** - Open with violence already happening - Fill in setup through fragments - Less "professional" structure - Matches pulp pacing **What if we don't know her background at first?** - Let readers wonder how she's doing this - Reveal through action, not exposition - Makes her more mysterious and human (people don't narrate their own CVs) ## Character Complications **Maya as less heroic:** - What if she's on probation for assault? (History of violence, not noble military service) - What if she's high when it starts? (Weed, pills—has to fight while impaired) - What if she's a fuckup in most of her life, this is just the one thing she's good at? - What if she's doing this job to case the house for robbery? (Morally compromised from start) - What if she genuinely considers running and leaving the kids? **The kids as more complex:** - Emma is at a bratty age, has been mean to Maya all night - One of them is disabled, adding real complication - They fight with each other during crisis - One of them doesn't trust Maya or actively gets in the way - Josh (5) doesn't understand and keeps asking to watch TV **Antagonists as more human/worse:** - One is chatty, tells her about his kids (making him human but not sympathetic) - One is explicitly, violently misogynistic (makes the revenge more satisfying, adds real ugliness) - They're not all professionals—one is new, scared, fucks up - Give them a chance to leave and they choose to stay (greed, pride) - Make their deaths varied in tone (one is satisfying, one is disturbing, one is just sad) ## Structural Chaos **Things that could genuinely surprise:** - Parents come home early (now Maya has to protect/manage them too) - One of the crew is someone from Maya's past - A neighbor intervenes and dies (adding guilt) - Police show up mid-story and Maya has to hide what's happening - The drive contains something that implicates Maya - One of the parents hired the crew (darker implications) **Messier timeline:** - Not one night—maybe it spills into dawn, next day - Time skips and fragments during trauma - Non-linear storytelling during action (adrenaline time distortion) ## Tonal Risks **Genuine ugliness:** - Maya is injured in ways that matter (broken fingers, concussion—affects her ability) - The house is destroyed in ways that feel real (family photos burned, kids' rooms trashed—emotional weight) - Someone says something unforgivable that we don't move past - A pet dies (arbitrary cruelty that can't be avenged) - Maya does something she can't take back (kills someone who was surrendering? Goes too far?) **Moral discomfort:** - The revenge feels wrong even as we want it - Maya becomes cruel in ways that disturb us - The ending doesn't justify the means - We're complicit in wanting violence - No clear catharsis, just exhaustion **Pulp weirdness:** - Lean into genre in unexpected ways (give Maya a repeating phrase or tic) - Make the violence stylized but specific (not cinematic, but described in tactile detail) - Include elements that are almost surreal (adrenaline makes things feel unreal) - Embrace exploitation elements while staying human (this is trash, but honest trash) ## Prose Specifics **Voice options:** - Profanity as punctuation (real people curse constantly under stress) - Sentence fragments during action (thought breaks down) - Hyper-specific brand names and details (grounds it in real world) - Technical language used wrong (she's stressed, misremembers terms) - Internal monologue that's not eloquent (stupid observations, dark humor, panic) **Rhythm:** - Vary chapter lengths (why are they all 1000 words? That's artificial) - Include a very short chapter (single scene, high impact) - Include sections of white space (passage of time, dissociation) - Let some scenes run long and breathless ## Ending Alternatives **Instead of resolution:** - End with her in custody, unsure if she's in trouble - End with her leaving town, no closure with kids - End with her going to kill Serrano and cut to black (we don't see it) - End with her trying to go back to normal and failing (traumatized, can't hold a cup without shaking) - End with ambiguity about whether she's become something worse **Instead of new purpose:** - She's just... done. Broke. Has to rebuild from nothing. - She does it again (becomes a vigilante, but framed as addiction not heroism) - She turns herself in (guilt wins) - She disappears (no redemption, just escape) ## What A Human Might Do Differently A human writer with this prompt ("They fucked with the wrong babysitter") might: 1. **Start with the title/concept and go wild** - Not plan 8 balanced chapters, but write until it's done 2. **Have a specific inspiration** - "What if HOME ALONE but genuinely violent?" or "Die Hard meets The Professional" 3. **Write scenes out of order** - Start with the most exciting part, fill in around it 4. **Let character voice lead** - Hear Maya talking and follow that, not structure 5. **Include personal obsessions** - Specific weapons they know about, neighborhoods they've lived in, real fears 6. **Make it uncomfortable for themselves** - Push into territory that's hard to write 7. **Kill darlings immediately** - That great ending idea? Maybe trash it for something rawer 8. **Write drunk/edit sober** (metaphorically) - First draft is excessive, then pull back 9. **Let it be stupid sometimes** - Pulp is allowed to be dumb, contrived, excessive 10. **Not explain everything** - Leave gaps, mysteries, things that don't pay off The current plan is a professional, competent outline for a story that hits its marks. A human writer might make something messier, meaner, more specific, more obsessive, more unbalanced—and possibly better for it.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention **Core Premise:** A young woman babysitting two kids becomes the wrong fucking person to mess with when a crew of criminals invades the home. This is pulp—excessive, violent, morally murky, and viscerally satisfying. The emphasis is on raw momentum over neat structure, emotion over tactics, and catharsis over character growth. **Protagonist:** Casey Winters, 22. Not military—she's a local girl who grew up fighting. Older brother was a golden gloves boxer who taught her young; she spent her teens doing unsanctioned amateur fights for money (and anger management issues). She's been in juvie, been in bad relationships, works three jobs including babysitting for rich families in a neighborhood she'll never afford. She's smart in a specific way—street smart, fight smart—but her life is kind of a mess. She's not trying to escape a violent past; violence is just a tool she knows how to use, like some people know Excel. This isn't a hero's journey. This is a bad night that goes very, very badly for the wrong people. **Antagonists:** Four-person crew, but make them real assholes: - **Vic** - the leader, smug professional who talks too much, makes sexual comments, underestimates Casey because she's young and female - **Len** - older guy, been doing this forever, casual cruelty, tells stories about other jobs - **Paulie** - younger, nervous, this might be his first real job, wants to prove himself (most dangerous because of that) - **Sadie** - the woman on the crew, which should make things complicated but doesn't; she's maybe the cruelest, has things to prove too They're after a safe with cash and jewelry—the Mersons are wealthy and stupid about it. But they expected the family to be at a wedding upstate overnight. Casey being there is the surprise. Then the kids being there is the disaster (parents changed plans last minute, didn't tell the crew's inside source). **The Kids:** - **Becca**, 10 - smart, scared, angry that Casey's there at all (she's old enough to stay alone, she thinks). Has a contentious relationship with Casey throughout. - **Dylan**, 4 - doesn't understand what's happening, keeps asking questions, can't be quiet They're not locked away safely. Casey tries, but it doesn't work. They're present, complicating things, in danger, and sometimes making it worse. **Structure & Pacing:** Fuck the perfect 1000-word chapters. They'll average that, but some will be shorter, some longer, as needed: - Ch 1 (1000): Setup, but start late—Casey already annoyed, kids already difficult, night already going badly before it gets worse - Ch 2 (800): Invasion happens fast—short, breathless chapter - Ch 3 (1200): First confrontation, messy and desperate - Ch 4 (1000): Failed escape attempt, things get worse - Ch 5 (1100): The turn, but it's not empowerment—it's desperation becoming rage - Ch 6 (900): Hunting them, but she's hurt and it's ugly - Ch 7 (1000): Climax with Vic, personal and brutal - Ch 8 (1000): Aftermath that doesn't resolve cleanly **Voice & Style:** First person, present tense. Casey's voice—profane, dark humor as defense mechanism, observant in specific ways (notices things about how people move, fight tells, exits), not eloquent but sharp. Internal monologue that's honest about fear, rage, even ugly thoughts. Short sentences during action. Fragments. Repetition when she's panicking. Specific brand names and local details. She calls it like she sees it. **Tone:** Pulp with real consequences. The violence is excessive but feels physical—it hurts, it's tiring, it's messier than movies. Dark humor punctuates horror. Moral ambiguity—Casey does things that might be too far, and we sit with that discomfort. No therapy-speak, no clean realizations. She's not fighting because she's accepted herself; she's fighting because stopping means dying. **Aiming For:** - Visceral, specific violence (not torture porn, but real and physical) - Protagonist who makes mistakes, gets hurt badly, sometimes makes it worse - Kids who are realistically difficult and present - Antagonists human enough to be genuinely hateable - Messy, desperate action over tactical competence - Dark humor and profanity as authenticity - An ending that satisfies the revenge fantasy but doesn't feel morally tidy - Momentum over structure—it should feel a bit out of control - Specific details that ground it (real place names, brands, Casey's specific knowledge) **Avoiding:** - Clean character arcs or emotional resolution - Perfect tactical thinking—she improvises, fucks up, gets lucky - Kids as props—they complicate everything - Noble motivations—she's fighting to survive and because she's pissed - Explaining the theme or having Casey realize things too clearly - Wrapping it up with a bow—no new career, no acceptance, just survival - Sanitized violence—if we're doing pulp revenge, commit to it - Symmetrical structure—let some chapters be weird lengths, some scenes run different **Key Choice - What Makes Her "Wrong":** Not that she's secretly trained. She's just fucking mean when she needs to be, has spent her life learning how to hurt people, and has no illusions about violence. She's been underestimated her whole life—by teachers, cops, the rich families she works for. These guys make the same mistake. That's what kills them. # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1: "Babysitting Pays Shit" (~1000 words) **START LATE, ALREADY ANNOYED** First person, present tense. Casey arrives at the Merson house—massive place in Whitfield Estates, the neighborhood where old money pretends it's still relevant. She's done this gig six times; easy money for watching streaming services while rich kids sleep. But tonight's different: Mrs. Merson changed plans, kids are here, and Becca is furious about having a babysitter at all. "I'm ten. I don't need some townie watching me." Establish Casey's voice immediately: profane internal monologue, chip on her shoulder about rich people, observant about details (notices the cheap lock on the back door, the security system they probably never arm, the obvious safe location in the master bedroom). She's been casing houses like this her whole life—not to rob them, just habit from growing up broke and pissed off. Dylan won't go to bed. Becca won't talk to her except to be snide. Casey's phone battery is dying and she forgot her charger. Already a shit night. She's in the kitchen making coffee she's not supposed to drink when she hears the back door—the one with the cheap lock—open quietly. Someone's inside the house. **Ends:** "I'm standing in the kitchen with a coffee mug in my hand, and I hear footsteps in the hallway. Multiple people. Moving quiet. And I think: fuck." ## Chapter 2: "Already Inside" (~800 words) **FAST, BREATHLESS, FEAR** No time to think. Casey moves—gets to the stairs, up to the kids' rooms. Becca's awake, reading with headphones in. Casey scares the shit out of her pulling them off: "Where's Dylan?" Guest room. Casey gets them both, hand over Dylan's mouth because he's already asking questions too loud. Trying to think. Upstairs bathroom has a lock. Gets them in there, tells Becca: "Lock this behind me. Don't open it. I'm going to get help." Becca, suddenly young and terrified: "What's happening?" Casey lies: "Probably nothing. Stay quiet." Back to the hallway. She can hear them downstairs—not trying to be quiet anymore. Male voices, laughing. "Told you they'd be gone." Someone else: "Just get the fucking safe open." Casey's thinking: get out, get to a neighbor, call 911. She starts down the stairs, quiet in socks. She's halfway down when the floorboard creaks. Everything stops. Voice from the living room: "The fuck was that?" Casey runs. Back up the stairs, but Paulie's already coming up—young guy, wire-thin, gun in his hand but he's holding it wrong, he's scared too. They collide at the landing. Pure instinct: Casey learned young that if someone has a weapon and you're close enough, you take it or you die. She goes for the gun. **Ends:** They go down the stairs together, grappling. It's ugly—elbows and knees and his teeth catch her forearm. The gun goes off. Loud as fuck. Casey doesn't know if she's shot until she realizes she's on top of him at the bottom of the stairs and he's not moving and there's blood. ## Chapter 3: "Not How This Was Supposed to Go" (~1200 words) **MESSY, DESPERATE, FIRST BLOOD** Casey's on the floor with a dead guy (Paulie—shot himself in the struggle, she thinks, can't tell, there's too much blood) and his gun in her hand and three other people in the house. Adrenaline makes everything sharp and distant at once. Her forearm is bleeding where he bit her—human bites are fucking dirty, she'll need antibiotics, why is she thinking about this? Get up. Move. But she doesn't know where they are. She can hear shouting: "Paulie? The fuck was that shot?" Heavy footsteps. She scrambles behind the couch as two of them come into the hallway—older guy (Len) and a woman (Sadie). They see Paulie. Len: "Shit. SHIT. Vic, we got a problem!" Casey's trying not to breathe. The gun is slippery in her hand—blood, sweat, both. She's never shot anyone. She's been in a lot of fights, but this is different. She should shoot them. They have guns too. But her hands are shaking and she's behind a couch and they're right there. Sadie sees her. Time slows in that cliché way that's actually true. Sadie's bringing up her gun and Casey fires first—misses, hits the wall, but Sadie and Len dive for cover. Casey runs—through the dining room, toward the kitchen, thinking maybe the back door, but Vic (the leader, older, calm) is coming from there. He's got his gun up but he's not shooting. He's smiling. "Easy. Easy there, sweetheart. You're the babysitter, right? You're having a bad night. We're all having a bad night now. But we can work this out." Casey backs up. She's got the gun pointed at him but her hands are shaking visibly. He keeps talking, closing distance. "What's your name? Casey? That's a nice name. Casey, you just killed my friend. But I get it—accident, self-defense. You're scared. But here's the thing—" She shoots him. Misses again—she's not used to pistols, the recoil jerks her hand up—but close enough that he stops smiling. He dives back and Casey runs again, this time up the back stairs (servants' stairs, because of course this house has those). Her mind is screaming: get the kids, get out. But how? They're between her and every exit. **Ends:** She gets to the bathroom. Becca unlocks it. Both kids staring at her—she's got blood on her shirt, a gun in her hand, she's panting. Dylan starts crying. Becca: "What's happening?" Casey: "We're leaving. Right now." ## Chapter 4: "No Way Out" (~1000 words) **FAILED ESCAPE, RAISING STAKES** The plan: second-floor window, drop to the porch roof, get to the ground, run to neighbors. It's a shit plan but it's all she has. Casey gets the window open—old house, swollen frame, loud as fuck doing it. She lifts Dylan up. "You're going to climb out onto the roof, okay? Like a game." He's crying too hard to answer. Becca goes first—braver than Casey gave her credit for. Out onto the porch roof, then Casey hands Dylan to her. Casey's climbing out when she hears them on the stairs. Len's voice: "They're up here somewhere." Casey's half out the window when Len kicks the door in. He sees them. Casey shoots—actually hits him this time, in the shoulder, he spins and goes down. But now they know where she is and gunshots answer hers, punching through the bathroom wall. Casey pulls herself out, slams the window. On the roof with two kids. Becca's frozen at the edge. "I can't jump." It's ten feet to the ground—not bad for Casey, maybe okay for Becca, but Dylan will break something. Casey's looking for options—there's a trellis, maybe—when bullets punch through the roof near her feet. They're shooting from inside. Fuck. New plan. Casey grabs both kids, moves along the roof to another window—locked. She smashes it with the gun, reaches in, unlocks it. Guest bedroom. They climb back inside. Becca: "Why are we going back in?"
