I'm here to deliver a message." "What message?" "The Mersons are moving. Witness protection or just away, I don't know. Your evidence is gone—cops seized everything from that house. Your window's closed. And if anything happens to those kids, to that family, to me—this phone goes to the FBI. With your contact info. With everything Vic had on it." He's quiet for a long moment. "That's extortion." "That's insurance. Walk away. Find a new mark. Forget this ever happened." "And if I don't?" "Then you're betting I'm more scared of you than you should be of me." I lower the gun. "I killed four people last week. You really want to find out if I'll kill a fifth?" I walk away. Waiting for a bullet in the back that doesn't come. Get in my car. Drive. I'm shaking so hard I have to pull over two blocks away. --- The Mersons leave town a week later. I know because Mrs. Merson calls, asks if I can come say goodbye to the kids. I almost say no. But I go. They're in the driveway, loading a moving truck. Dylan sees me first. Runs over, crashes into my legs. I pick him up. He's gotten heavier. "Where are you going?" I ask. "Grammy's house. In California. We get to see the ocean." "That's good." Becca's standing by the truck. Not coming over. Just watching. I put Dylan down. Walk over to her. "Hey," I say. "Hi." She's different. Quieter. The bratty attitude's gone. Replaced by something else. Something older. "You okay?" I ask. "Are you?" I don't answer that. "I'm sorry you saw what you saw," I tell her. "I'm not." She looks up at me. "You kept us safe. You did what you had to do." She sounds like she's trying to convince herself. Mrs. Merson calls her. Time to go. Becca hugs me—quick, tight—then runs to the car. I watch them drive away. --- Two weeks later I'm at Dunkin', making coffee for the morning rush. My manager asked if I wanted time off. I said no. I need normal. Need routine. My hands shake sometimes. When it's quiet. When I'm alone. The bite scar's healing. Raised and pink, gonna be permanent. My elbow still hurts when it rains. I sleep four hours a night if I'm lucky. Hailey says I should talk to someone. A therapist. I told her I'm fine. I'm not fine. But I'm here. The kids are safe. And I'm still the girl who works three jobs and sends money to her dad and visits Tommy once a month and lives in a studio above a laundromat. Except now I'm also the girl who killed four people. I can live with that. I have to. The next customer orders a large iced coffee. I make it. Hand it over. Say have a nice day like I mean it. My phone buzzes. Text from a number I don't know: *My sister needs a bodyguard. Heard you're good. Interested?* I stare at it for a long time. Delete it. Clock out. Go home. Lie in bed and stare at the ceiling. Tomorrow I'll do it again. And the day after. And the day after that. That's what survival looks like. Not pretty. Not fixed. Not better. Just still breathing. --- END
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter succeeds in delivering the "messy, desperate" aftermath promised in the writing plan, avoiding clean resolution while maintaining the authentic voice established throughout. The model demonstrates strong adherence to both the prompt's core premise and its own structural intentions. The character work remains solid. Casey's voice stays consistent - profane, direct, wrestling with trauma without therapeutic language or neat emotional arcs. Her interactions feel genuine, particularly the painful scene with Becca where the child's changed perspective ("You did what you had to do") carries real weight. The model avoids the trap of having Casey suddenly become wise or healed. Plot-wise, the chapter handles necessary aftermath beats efficiently: medical treatment, police questioning, media attention, and the Merson family's departure. The burner phone subplot adds tension and demonstrates Casey's continued agency rather than passive victimhood. The confrontation with the crime boss, while brief, serves its purpose of showing Casey's evolution into someone comfortable wielding violence as leverage. The writing maintains the established style effectively. Concrete details ground the narrative (eleven stitches, specific hospital procedures, DMV photo). Dialogue feels natural, particularly Dylan's innocent questions contrasted with Becca's new gravity. The model resists purple prose and forced metaphors, keeping the voice authentic to Casey's perspective. However, some sections feel rushed or summary-like rather than fully dramatized. The crime boss confrontation, while functional, could have been more developed to increase tension. The emotional impact of certain moments - Casey's hospital solitude, the goodbye scene - could have been deepened without betraying the character's emotional reticence. The ending achieves the promised tone of survival without redemption. Casey's rejection of the bodyguard job offer and return to routine work reinforces themes of working-class persistence rather than transformation. The final lines effectively capture the unglamorous reality of moving forward after trauma. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is a well-executed pulp revenge story that successfully delivers on its premise. The narrative follows Casey, a working-class babysitter who becomes trapped in a home invasion and must protect two children while fighting off armed intruders. The story effectively subverts expectations by revealing Casey's hidden fighting background and escalating her from victim to predator. Strengths include believable character development, particularly Casey's transformation from defensive protector to aggressive killer. Her background in underground fighting and training from her imprisoned brother provides solid foundation for her combat skills. The author handles the psychological aftermath thoughtfully, showing Casey's trauma and the children's changed perception of her. The pacing builds tension effectively across chapters, with each escalation feeling earned. The world-building creates a convincing contrast between Casey's working-class struggles and the wealthy Merson family's lifestyle. Details about the house layout, security vulnerabilities, and socioeconomic differences feel authentic and serve the plot well. The children's dialogue and reactions are age-appropriate and realistic. The action sequences are well-written with clear choreography and visceral impact. The violence feels consequential rather than gratuitous, and the author doesn't shy away from the psychological toll. The aftermath chapters add depth by exploring trauma and showing how the experience fundamentally changes all involved. Weaknesses include some predictable villain dialogue and motivations. The criminals fall into familiar archetypes without much depth beyond their function in the plot. Some plot conveniences (like the crawlspace hiding spot) feel slightly contrived. The mysterious employer subplot, while adding intrigue, feels somewhat underdeveloped. The prose style is appropriately direct for pulp fiction, avoiding purple prose while maintaining engagement. The narrative voice remains consistent throughout, and exposition generally feels natural rather than forced. The story maintains coherence across its multiple chapters and delivers emotional impact alongside the action. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Pacing: 17 World Building: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19
Avg Final Item Score: 79.3/100
+ Queer Neo-Noir Romance — Cigarette Smoke & Bad Ideas (Chapter Avg: 80.9 | Final: 82.2)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Queer Neo-Noir Romance Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Queer Neo-Noir Romance Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming ## Genre Elements to Consider **Neo-Noir:** - Urban decay, night scenes, rain-slicked streets - Morally ambiguous characters - Crime elements (murder, theft, corruption) - Femme fatale archetype (can be gender-flipped or queered) - Voice-over style narration or first-person retrospective - Atmospheric lighting, shadows, neon signs - Cynicism, fatalism, betrayal - Private investigators, criminals, cops - Past sins catching up with characters **Queer Romance:** - LGBTQ+ protagonists - Found family themes - Identity exploration or acceptance - Community/safe spaces (queer bars, underground scenes) - Societal pressures/homophobia as additional noir tension - Authentic representation of desire and relationship dynamics ## Character Possibilities **Option 1: The Narrator (POV character)** - A jaded bartender at a queer dive bar - A recovering addict trying to stay clean - A former cop kicked off the force - A private investigator specializing in finding runaways - A photographer documenting the underground scene - A writer researching a book about the city's underbelly **Option 2: "He" (The cigarette smoke and bad ideas)** - A con artist with a death wish - A drug dealer with a code of honor - A hitman trying to get out of the game - A musician in a self-destructive spiral - A thief planning one last job - A witness to a crime on the run ## Plot Possibilities **Scenario A: The Missing Person** - Narrator is hired/asked to find someone - "He" knows where they are or what happened - The search reveals a larger conspiracy - Romance develops during investigation - Twist: the missing person wanted to disappear **Scenario B: The Setup** - "He" pulls narrator into a scheme (heist, con, revenge plot) - Romance complicates the professional relationship - Someone is playing both of them - They must decide whether to trust each other - Ends with difficult choice between love and survival **Scenario C: The Witness Protection** - Narrator is in hiding after witnessing a crime - "He" is assigned to protect them (or claims to be) - Forced proximity breeds attraction - Question of whether "he" can be trusted - Real threats close in on them **Scenario D: The Past Returns** - Narrator and "he" have history together - "He" reappears after years with a problem/danger - Old feelings resurface alongside old wounds - They must confront what went wrong before - Mystery from the past needs solving **Scenario E: The Frame Job** - Narrator is accused of a crime they didn't commit - "He" is the only one who believes them (or claims to) - Together they search for the real culprit - Sexual tension builds during close partnership - Discovery that one of them knows more than they're saying ## Setting Options - Contemporary major city (New York, Los Angeles, Chicago) - Rust belt city in decline (Detroit, Pittsburgh) - Southern city with old money and secrets (New Orleans, Atlanta) - Pacific Northwest rain and shadows (Seattle, Portland) - Fictional city that allows more creative freedom ## Tone Variations - Hard-boiled and cynical throughout - Starts cynical, softens toward romance - Dark comedy elements - Melancholic and atmospheric - Tension between hope (romance) and despair (noir) ## Story Structure Across 8 Chapters **Act 1 (Chapters 1-2): Setup** - Introduce narrator and their world - "He" enters/re-enters the picture - Inciting incident/problem presented - Initial attraction/tension established **Act 2A (Chapters 3-4): Rising Action** - Investigation/scheme begins - Characters forced together - First major complication - Romance begins to develop - Trust issues emerge **Act 2B (Chapters 5-6): Complications** - Major setback or betrayal - Romantic relationship deepens or fractures - New information changes everything - Physical danger increases - Emotional stakes raised **Act 3 (Chapters 7-8): Resolution** - Climax of both mystery/crime plot and romance - Truth revealed - Confrontation with antagonist - Decision point: safety or love, truth or happiness - Resolution: ambiguous or hopeful noir ending ## Specific Story Beats Ideas - Opening in a rain-soaked alley or smoky bar - A corpse discovered - A kiss that complicates everything - A car chase or foot pursuit - A confrontation in a liminal space (parking garage, rooftop, pier) - A moment of vulnerability/confession - A double-cross - A choice to save the other at personal cost ## Narrative Voice Options - First person, present tense (immediate and intimate) - First person, past tense (reflective noir narration) - Third person limited (more traditional) - Dual POV alternating (risky with 8 short chapters) # Reflection Looking at these brainstormed elements, I need to find the combination that will: 1. Honor the noir genre while centering a queer romance 2. Create a complete arc in 8,000 words 3. Balance plot/mystery with character/romance development 4. Make "cigarette smoke and bad ideas" feel essential, not just decorative **What works:** The **dual-timeline or past-returns structure** (Scenario D) has strong potential. If the narrator and "he" have history, we get built-in emotional stakes, the noir theme of past sins, and can reveal backstory while moving plot forward. This could create excellent tension between who they were and who they've become. **The frame job or setup scenarios** (B and E) work well for forced proximity and the "are they trustworthy" tension central to noir. This naturally creates both romantic and suspense beats. The **first-person retrospective narration** feels most noir-appropriate and allows for that world-weary, poetic voice the genre is known for. Lines like "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas" fit perfectly in this mode. For **setting**, a specific city with atmosphere (New Orleans for heat and decay, Seattle/Portland for rain and shadows) would be better than generic. The location can become a character itself. **Character-wise**, I'm drawn to making the narrator someone trying to live a quieter life who gets pulled back into chaos. "He" should be genuinely dangerous/damaged but not irredeemable—charismatic enough that we understand the attraction despite the red flags. **What needs consideration:** Eight chapters is tight for both a mystery plot AND a romance arc. I need to make sure the plot isn't too convoluted. The crime/noir element should be straightforward enough to resolve while still having twists. Something personal rather than a sprawling conspiracy would work better. The **romance needs to feel earned** in this short space. Either they have history (so we're seeing rekindling/resolution) or the chemistry needs to be so electric that quick development feels believable. Noir's fatalistic "we're doomed but I want you anyway" energy could help accelerate this. **Balancing the genres:** Noir tends toward betrayal and dark endings, while romance traditionally requires emotional satisfaction. Neo-noir allows more flexibility—I can aim for hopeful-but-ambiguous, or bittersweet-but-authentic. The relationship can be the one true thing in a world of lies, or it can be complicated by deception that's ultimately forgiven/understood. **Avoiding stereotypes:** "Cigarette smoke and bad ideas" could easily become a shallow bad-boy trope. Need to give "he" real depth, vulnerability, reasons for his choices. The queerness should be integral, not incidental—perhaps external homophobia adds to noir's themes of society's corruption, or queer community becomes the found-family element that offers hope. **Pacing concern:** With 1000 words per chapter, I have limited space. Each chapter needs to accomplish multiple things: advance plot, develop character, build romance, maintain atmosphere. Need to avoid chapters that are just exposition or just action. **Strong opening:** Starting with that line "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas" as either the literal first line or within the first paragraph is essential. It sets tone immediately and promises the reader what kind of story this is. **The best synthesis seems to be:** - Narrator: Someone trying to stay out of trouble (former PI, ex-con, recovering addict, retired thief) - "He": An ex-lover or old partner-in-crime who returns with a problem - Plot: Relatively focused crime (a murder, a stolen item, a debt to dangerous people) that forces them together - Setting: Atmospheric city with queer spaces featured - Arc: Investigation brings them close again, old feelings return, truth about the past emerges, they must choose whether to trust each other in the climax - Ending: Noir-inflected but allows for connection—maybe they survive but changed, maybe they choose each other despite costs This framework allows for atmospheric writing, genuine mystery, charged romance between people with baggage, and can be executed in 8,000 words without feeling rushed or incomplete.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention ## Core Concept A queer neo-noir romance about two former lovers—a reformed private investigator trying to live clean and the charismatic, self-destructive con artist who broke his heart—forced back together when the past literally comes knocking in the form of a murder accusation. ## Plot Structure **The Crime/Mystery:** "He" (Danny) is accused of murdering a wealthy closeted businessman. He claims he's being framed and needs the narrator's help to prove it. The investigation reveals the murder is connected to a blackmail scheme from five years ago—a scheme both of them were involved in before the narrator walked away from that life. The real killer is someone from their shared past seeking revenge. **The Romance:** This is a rekindling story. The narrator (Miles) and Danny were partners in crime and lovers until Miles got clean/straight and Danny didn't. The story explores whether people can truly change, whether trust can be rebuilt, and whether love is worth the risk of returning to a dangerous life. ## Narrative Voice & Style - **First person past tense** (Miles narrating retrospectively—he's telling us a story that's already happened, allowing for noir's reflective, poetic voice) - **Hard-boiled but emotional**: Cynical observations about the world, but vulnerable about feelings for Danny - **Atmospheric**: Rain, neon, smoke, late nights, dive bars, empty streets - **Spare prose with poetic moments**: Noir imagery, sharp dialogue, economical description - **Opening line will be**: "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas, and he was standing in my doorway like the past five years hadn't happened." ## Setting **Pacific Northwest city (Seattle-inspired but unnamed)**: Rain-soaked streets, declining industrial waterfront, gentrifying neighborhoods, queer bars in Capitol Hill-esque district, wealthy enclaves on the hills. The weather and darkness are atmospheric constants. ## Characters **Miles Chen (Narrator, 34)**: - Former PI who specialized in "discreet" cases (often blackmail, following cheating spouses, digging up dirt) - Five years clean from alcohol and the criminal life - Works as a bartender at a queer dive bar called The Lighthouse - Asian-American, guarded, trying to believe he can be good - Still in love with Danny despite everything **Danny Torres (The "He," 33)**: - Con artist, charming liar, genuinely brilliant at reading people - Self-destructive streak a mile wide (cigarettes, risks, bad choices) - Latino, beautiful in a dangerous way, charismatic - Covers vulnerability with humor and bravado - Never stopped loving Miles but doesn't believe he deserves good things **Supporting Characters**: - **Lydia**: Miles's sponsor and friend, owner of The Lighthouse, protective - **Victor Chen**: The real killer—Miles's cousin, who went to prison for a crime that Miles and Danny's blackmail scheme inadvertently caused - **Marcus Webb**: The murdered businessman, closeted, was being blackmailed - **Detective Sarah Kovač**: Homicide detective, knows Miles's history, suspicious of both men ## Themes - Can people truly change, or just hide who they are? - Trust and betrayal in relationships - The noir concept of the past catching up with you - Queer life in straight spaces (closeted victim, exposure as weapon) - Found family vs. blood family - Redemption and whether it's possible ## What I'm Aiming For - Equal weight to mystery plot and romance - Genuine suspense about both whodunit and whether they'll end up together - Atmospheric noir writing that honors the genre - Authentic queer representation (not trauma-only, showing community) - Complex morality—no pure heroes or villains - Earned emotional beats - Satisfying resolution to both mystery and romance ## What I'm Avoiding - Overly complex mystery that requires too much exposition - Instalove (they have history, but rekindling should feel gradual) - Tragic queer ending (noir-tinged but ultimately hopeful) - Stereotypical "damaged bad boy" without depth - Info-dumping backstory - Stalling the plot for romance or vice versa ## Ending Miles and Danny solve the case and clear Danny's name by confronting Victor. In doing so, Miles must accept his own guilt about the past. The resolution allows both men to move forward—Danny begins to believe he deserves good things, Miles accepts he can love someone without losing himself. They choose each other, but with eyes open about who they both are. The final image: them together in Miles's apartment, Danny putting out a cigarette, Miles choosing him anyway. # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1: "Smoke Signals" (~1000 words) **Opening**: "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas, and he was standing in my doorway like the past five years hadn't happened." Miles is working late at The Lighthouse when Danny appears for the first time in five years. Establish Miles's current life (bartending, sober, quiet), the weight of their history through Miles's internal narration, and Danny's desperate situation. Danny reveals a wealthy man (Marcus Webb) has been murdered, and the police think Danny did it because he was seen leaving Webb's apartment building. Danny claims he's being framed. Miles wants to refuse but can't. **Beats**: Setup of Miles's world, Danny's entrance, murder revelation, Miles's reluctant agreement to help, immediate tension/attraction despite the years apart. ## Chapter 2: "The Scene of the Crime" (~1000 words) Miles and Danny visit Webb's apartment building under cover of darkness to investigate. Crime scene tape is gone but the doorman remembers Danny. Through investigation and dialogue, we learn: Webb was closeted, involved in city politics, killed in his home. Miles's investigative skills come back naturally. Physical proximity in tight spaces (elevator, hallway) creates charged moments. Danny's nervous energy manifests in chain-smoking and gallows humor. They find evidence Webb was being blackmailed (anonymous notes demanding money). Miles recognizes the pattern—it's similar to work they used to do. First major complication: this feels connected to their past. **Beats**: Investigation begins, their chemistry/old dynamic resurfaces, first clue that links to their past, rising tension. ## Chapter 3: "Old Ghosts" (~1000 words) Back at Miles's apartment (Danny has nowhere else to go), they're forced to discuss the past. Five years ago, they ran blackmail schemes together—Miles did the investigation, Danny did the con. Their last job went wrong somehow, and Miles walked away from both the life and Danny. Through tense dialogue, reveal that someone they targeted ended up dead (not directly their fault, but consequences of exposure), and Miles couldn't live with the guilt. Danny tried to keep going without him. In the present, they drink coffee and look through old case files Miles kept. They identify several past marks who might want revenge. The list includes Victor Chen—Miles's cousin who went to prison for embezzlement after they exposed him. Moment of vulnerability: Danny admits he tried to quit after Miles left but couldn't do it alone. Almost-kiss interrupted by a phone call. **Beats**: Backstory revealed through conflict, emotional intimacy, suspect list created, almost-kiss raises stakes. ## Chapter 4: "Following Shadows" (~1000 words) Miles and Danny split up to investigate suspects. Miles visits Victor in prison (now recently released) while Danny checks on other former marks. Cross-cutting between their separate investigations. Victor is cold, angry, claims he's gone straight but clearly harbors resentment toward Miles. Danny's investigation leads to dead ends but also to the neighborhood where Webb lived—he spots Detective Kovač watching him. They reconvene at The Lighthouse where Lydia is immediately suspicious of Danny and protective of Miles. She pulls Miles aside, warns him that Danny will drag him down again. Danny overhears part of it. Argument between Miles and Danny about trust—Danny accuses Miles of never believing he could change, Miles accuses Danny of never trying. Danny storms out. Miles drinks tonic water at the bar, staring at the door, and admits to Lydia (and himself) that he's still in love with Danny. **Beats**: Investigation widens, Lydia as voice of reason/concern, major argument that addresses core relationship issue, Miles's admission of love. ## Chapter 5: "The Lighthouse Keeper" (~1000 words) Danny doesn't return that night. Miles is worried but tells himself it's not his problem. At dawn, Detective Kovač arrives at Miles's apartment with questions—she knows about their past and suspects they're interfering with her investigation. She reveals new information: Webb's phone records show calls to Danny going back six months. Was Danny involved with Webb? Was this personal? Miles defends Danny but doubts creep in. He tracks Danny down at a cheap motel, finds him drunk and chain-smoking. Confrontation: Danny admits he knew Webb, was sleeping with him casually, but swears he didn't kill him. He also reveals Webb was being blackmailed by someone else—Danny was trying to find out who because he felt protective of Webb. Miles has to decide whether to believe him. Moment of truth: Danny breaks down, admits he's tired of running, of being the disaster everyone expects. Miles chooses to trust him. They sleep together (intimate scene, emotionally charged, reconnecting physically and emotionally). **Beats**: Trust crisis, new information complicates everything, Danny's vulnerability, Miles's choice to believe, intimate reunion. ## Chapter 6: "Patterns in the Dark" (~1000 words) Morning after. They wake tangled together, and for a moment, it's like the old days. But the case still looms. Together, they analyze what they know: the blackmail pattern, Webb's connections, who would have access to their old methods. Miles realizes the blackmailer is using techniques Miles specifically developed—someone who watched them work. They return to the idea of Victor. Research reveals he was released three weeks before the blackmail letters started. He has motive (revenge), opportunity (knows their methods), and means. But they need proof before going to Kovač. They stake out Victor's apartment. During the long night watch, more intimate conversation—Danny asks if Miles is happy now, if leaving him was worth it. Miles admits he's been half-alive without Danny, but also that he couldn't have survived staying. Danny admits he wants to be better, to be someone Miles could build a life with. They spot Victor leaving with a package. They follow. **Beats**: Morning-after intimacy, breakthrough in the case, stakeout allows for deep conversation, pursuit begins. ## Chapter 7: "The Frame Cracks" (~1000 words) Following Victor leads to a confrontation in the industrial waterfront district (atmospheric: rain, shipping containers, isolation). Victor admits everything—he's been planning this for five years. He blackmailed Webb using Miles's old techniques specifically to frame Danny. He killed Webb when the man threatened to go to the police, knowing Danny would be blamed because of their relationship. His goal: destroy both of them the way they destroyed his life. Fight scene—Victor has a gun. Danny tries to talk him down while Miles circles around. Victor reveals that the embezzlement charge sent him to prison where he lost everything; his bitterness has festered. He's going to kill them both and make it look like a murder-suicide. Miles tackles Victor, gun goes off, Danny gets the weapon. They subdue Victor just as Kovač arrives (Miles had texted her their location earlier). Victor is arrested, confession recorded. They're in the clear. But in the chaos, Miles is grazed by the bullet—not serious, but bleeding. Danny's panic over Miles being hurt reveals the depth of his feelings. **Beats**: Confrontation with killer, truth revealed, action sequence, Miles injured, case resolved, emotional revelation through crisis. ## Chapter 8: "New Light" (~1000 words) Epilogue tone. Miles gets stitched up at the hospital, Danny refuses to leave his side. Kovač takes their statements, warns them to stay out of trouble, but there's a hint of respect. The case is closed. Back at Miles's apartment in the early morning light. The immediate danger is over, but now they have to decide what comes next. Danny says he should leave, that he's still bad news, that Miles deserves better. Miles tells him that he's tired of playing it safe if safe means being alone. Danny admits he's scared—of failing Miles again, of being the reason Miles relapses or gets hurt. Miles says he's scared too, but that he wants to try anyway. They agree to take it slow, that Danny will get his own place, maybe find real work, that they'll date like normal people. Final image: Danny lights a cigarette on the fire escape, Miles joins him with coffee. Danny asks if Miles really wants this—all the cigarette smoke and bad ideas. Miles takes the cigarette from Danny's hand, stubs it out, and kisses him. "I want you," he says. "We'll work on the rest." The city wakes up around them. For the first time in years, the rain has stopped. **Beats**: Aftermath, emotional resolution, decision to be together, acknowledgment of challenges ahead, hopeful ending that honors both noir realism and romance, final callback to opening line, symbol of new beginning (rain stopping).
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# The Human Writing Process vs. LLM Tendencies ## How a Human Writer Might Approach This Prompt A human writer encountering "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas" for a queer neo-noir romance would likely: 1. **Start with a feeling or image**, not a complete plot structure. Maybe they're drawn to the self-destructive romance angle, or they have a vivid mental image of someone in a doorway backlit by neon, or they're working through their own experience with a chaotic ex. 2. **Discover the story through writing**. They might not know whodunit until chapter 4. They might realize a character needs to exist only when they write themselves into a corner. The mystery might start as one thing and become another. 3. **Have obsessions and blind spots**. Human writers return to certain themes, images, relationship dynamics. They over-write what fascinates them and under-write what bores them. The story would be unbalanced in interesting ways. 4. **Let characters surprise them**. A human writer might plan for Danny to be one way and discover he's actually more vulnerable, or more manipulative, or funnier than expected. 5. **Leave threads hanging**. Not everything resolves. Some details are red herrings not because of craft but because the writer forgot about them or changed direction. 6. **Write scenes that don't "serve" the plot** but feel real to the characters or atmosphere. A whole chapter in a bar that's mostly mood. A digression about Miles's relationship with his family that doesn't connect to Victor. 7. **Have a messier emotional arc**. The characters might sleep together too early and then regret it. Or not sleep together at all and the tension stays unresolved. The ending might be more ambiguous about whether they'll actually make it. 8. **Draw from personal experience** in ways that make specific details vivid and others vague. They know exactly what that bar smells like but are fuzzy on police procedure. ## Common LLM Writing Pitfalls ### General LLM Tendencies: 1. **Excessive symmetry and balance**: Every setup has a payoff, every character has an arc, every theme is explored proportionally 2. **Over-explanation**: Characters articulate their feelings too clearly, narration explains subtext, motivations are spelled out 3. **Conflict resolution is too neat**: Misunderstandings are cleared up through conversation, everyone grows, endings tie up all threads 4. **Emotional safety**: Avoiding truly uncomfortable moments, pulling punches on darkness, ensuring likability 5. **Mechanical plot progression**: Every scene advances plot or character in visible ways, no meandering 6. **Functional dialogue**: People say what the plot needs them to say, not what they'd actually say 7. **Thematic obviousness**: Themes are stated and restated, symbols are explained 8. **Even pacing**: Each chapter does roughly equal work, no chapters that are just vibes 9. **Character consistency**: People act in psychologically coherent ways throughout, without real contradictions 10. **Writing to impress**: Prose that's polished to the point of smoothness, lacking roughness or voice 11. **Telegraphing**: Setups are too obvious, revelations aren't surprising 12. **Fair play**: Every character gets their moment, equal representation of perspectives 13. **Avoiding problematic elements**: Characters are progressive, no one does anything truly unforgivable, messy power dynamics are cleaned up ### Specific to This Genre: **For Noir:** - LLMs often make noir "aesthetic" without being genuinely dark—the rain and cigarettes are there but everyone's too functional and healing-oriented - Real noir has unsympathetic protagonists, unhealthy choices that don't get fully resolved, pessimism about human nature - LLMs struggle with moral ambiguity—they want to justify character actions rather than letting them be bad **For Romance:** - LLMs default to miscommunication plots resolved through honest conversation - Physical attraction is stated but not shown in truly visceral ways - Emotional progression is linear (distrust → trust → love) rather than messy - The relationship is "good for both of them" rather than complicated or even mutually destructive **For Queer Fiction:** - LLMs can be overly careful, making queerness a non-issue or only a source of external conflict (homophobia) rather than internal complexity - Avoiding messiness in queer relationships that straight relationships get—cheating, toxicity, power imbalances - Found family can become cliché without specific texture - Sex scenes are either fade-to-black or overly tasteful # Deep Dive Critique of My Plan ## Major LLM Tropes I'm Falling Into ### 1. **The Mystery Is Too Neat** **The Problem**: Victor as the killer is too symmetrical. He's Miles's cousin (family connection), he went to prison because of them (revenge motive), he uses their techniques (method connection), he's been planning for exactly five years (temporal symmetry). This is LLM "everything connects" plotting. **Why It's Not Human**: A human writer might have the killer be someone unexpected, or someone we barely met, or even—more noir—might not fully solve the mystery. The solution explains too much. Real noir often has loose ends, unclear motives, or reveals that don't answer everything. **What's Missing**: Ambiguity, coincidence, the sense that some things just happen without perfect causation. Maybe they never fully prove Victor did it. Maybe the evidence is circumstantial. Maybe Victor didn't plan to kill Webb—it was impulsive and the frame-up was opportunistic. ### 2. **The Romance Arc Is Too Clean** **The Problem**: - Chapter 1: They meet - Chapter 3: Almost kiss - Chapter 5: Sleep together at the emotional crisis point - Chapter 8: Commit to trying This is textbook romance structure. It hits beats on schedule. The sex happens at exactly the midpoint after Danny's vulnerability. **Why It's Not Human**: Real relationships, especially rekindling toxic ones, are messier. Maybe they sleep together immediately in Chapter 2 because they can't help it, then spend the rest of the story dealing with having complicated the situation. Or they don't sleep together at all and the story ends with just a kiss. Or they sleep together multiple times in different emotional registers. **What's Missing**: Bad timing, regret, physical relationship out of sync with emotional one, chemistry that makes them do stupid things, non-linear progression. ### 3. **Both Characters Grow Too Evenly** **The Problem**: Miles learns to love again and accept imperfection. Danny learns he deserves good things and can change. Both arcs complete, both men meet in the middle. It's fair, balanced, and deeply LLM. **Why It's Not Human**: Often in real relationships, one person grows and the other doesn't, or they grow at different rates, or growth isn't even the point. Maybe Miles doesn't really change—he was always going to choose Danny. Maybe Danny can't actually change and Miles chooses him anyway, accepting this is who he is. **What's Missing**: Asymmetry, acceptance without transformation, one person doing more emotional work, the possibility that love isn't about mutual growth. ### 4. **The Supporting Cast Is Too Functional** **The Problem**: - Lydia exists to warn Miles (voice of reason) - Kovač exists to be the law/obstacle - Victor exists to be the villain - Webb exists to be the corpse Each character has exactly one role and fulfills it. **Why It's Not Human**: Real people in stories have their own shit going on. Lydia might be dealing with her own drama that has nothing to do with Miles. Kovač might be more or less interested in the case for personal reasons. Supporting characters should feel like they exist when they're off-page. **What's Missing**: Subplots, contradictions in supporting characters, people who don't serve the plot, relationships between supporting characters, someone who's more important to the protagonist than their narrative function suggests. ### 5. **Every Scene Is Load-Bearing** **The Problem**: Every chapter does multiple jobs: advances plot, develops romance, reveals character, maintains atmosphere. It's efficient. It's comprehensive. It's too organized. **Why It's Not Human**: Human writers write scenes because they want to, because they're procrastinating on the hard part, because they're obsessed with a particular dynamic. Some scenes do one thing really well. Some scenes are self-indulgent. Some scenes should probably be cut but have a sentence too good to lose. **What's Missing**: Imbalance, a chapter that's all mood, a chapter that's just them arguing in circles, scenes that are more important emotionally than plotwise, digression. ### 6. **The Backstory Explains Everything** **The Problem**: Miles and Danny's past is a blackmail scheme that went wrong, someone died, Miles left due to guilt, Danny stayed in the life, Victor got caught. It all connects. Their personal relationship crisis directly causes the current plot. **Why It's Not Human**: Sometimes breakups are about something smaller and stupider. Sometimes the past crime and the past relationship are separate issues. Sometimes people don't know exactly why they split—it was a bunch of things, or one unforgivable thing that seems small in retrospect. **What's Missing**: Mundane reasons alongside dramatic ones, unresolved questions about why they really ended, the past being less clear-cut than either of them remembers. ### 7. **The Emotional Beats Are Clearly Signaled** **The Problem**: "Danny breaks down, admits he's tired of running." "Miles admits he's been half-alive without Danny." Characters explicitly state their emotional arcs, often directly before or after major plot points. **Why It's Not Human**: People rarely articulate their feelings that clearly, especially not noir protagonists. The emotion should come through in action, reaction, what they don't say, how they smoke a cigarette, the silences. **What's Missing**: Subtext, denial, characters who don't understand their own feelings, emotion shown through behavior rather than articulation, moments where feelings are clear to the reader but not stated. ### 8. **The Ending Resolves Too Much** **The Problem**: Case solved, villain caught, both men decide to try a relationship, they'll take it slow and do it right this time, the rain stops (literal pathetic fallacy), hopeful note. **Why It's Not Human**: This is splitting the difference between noir and romance in the most diplomatic LLM way. Real noir doesn't end with "we'll work on it." Real romance doesn't end with ambiguity about the relationship. A human writer would probably commit harder to one genre or the other, or find a more unexpected synthesis. **What's Missing**: A genuinely uncertain ending, or a genuinely romantic ending, not a hedge. Maybe they solve the case but don't get back together. Maybe they get back together but the case has loose ends. Maybe the ending is more about acceptance than hope. Maybe it's darker—they're together but we're not sure it's healthy. Maybe it's sweeter—they're together and fuck the noir conventions. ### 9. **The Noir Elements Are Aesthetic** **The Problem**: Rain, cigarettes, dive bars, neon, moral ambiguity—all present. But the actual moral content is pretty comfortable. Miles is sympathetic (guilt-ridden, sober, trying to be good), Danny is sympathetic (hurt, self-destructive but not actually evil), their crimes were blackmail where someone else committed the real violence. **Why It's Not Human**: Real noir makes you uncomfortable with the protagonist. They do unforgivable things. They make bad choices even when good ones are available. They might be racist, might hit someone, might throw someone under the bus to save themselves. Noir is about moral rot, not basically good people in atmospheric lighting. **What's Missing**: Genuinely difficult moral choices, protagonists who do something the reader won't excuse, complicity that's harder to justify, ending where they've won but lost something irretrievable. ### 10. **The Queer Elements Are Too Comfortable** **The Problem**: The Lighthouse is a safe space, Lydia is supportive found family, the queerness is mostly incidental to the plot except for Webb being closeted (which is symbolic/thematic). The protagonists' queerness isn't complicated. **Why It's Not Human**: Even in 2024, queer life has more texture than this. Internalized homophobia, community drama, different attitudes about visibility, class differences in how queerness is experienced, complicated relationships with queer spaces. And sometimes queerness IS incidental, but then why make it a "queer noir romance" specifically? **What's Missing**: Conflict within queer community, internalized issues, specific queer cultural references, the queerness mattering to the noir plot in unexpected ways (beyond just closeted victim), messier representation of queer spaces. ## Specific Line-Level Issues ### The Opening Line Usage **The Problem**: I plan to use "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas, and he was standing in my doorway like the past five years hadn't happened." **Why It's Too LLM**: This extends the prompt line in the most obvious way—adding context that explains it. It's smooth. It's complete. It's immediately clear who, what, when, where. **More Human Approach**: Maybe just use the line alone as the first line, with no addition. Maybe use it somewhere other than the opening—when Miles sees Danny the second time, or as an interior thought mid-argument. Maybe undercut it—use it seriously but then have Miles think something that contradicts or complicates it. ### Character Names **The Problem**: Miles Chen and Danny Torres. Victor Chen. Sarah Kovač. Lydia (no last name given). These are carefully diverse, contemporary, not stereotypical. **Why It's LLM**: It feels like balanced representation rather than organic naming. Why is Miles named Miles? Did his parents love jazz? Is it his chosen name? The names don't tell us much except demographics. **More Human Approach**: Names that mean something to the writer, that came from a specific person or character inspiration, that have texture (nicknames, full names we learn later, names that don't match the character, ethnic names that have assimilation stories behind them). ### The Timeline **The Problem**: Five years since they broke up. Victor released three weeks before blackmail starts. Eight chapters of exactly 1000 words each. The mystery happens over what, a week? Everything is measured. **Why It's LLM**: Perfect proportions. A human might make it four years, or seven, or "a few years" that never gets specified. The story might take three days or three months. Chapter lengths would vary wildly based on what's happening. **More Human Approach**: Messier timeline, some ambiguity about how long things take, chapters that vary in length based on content not arbitrary word count. # Brainstorming More Human Approaches ## Alternative Plot Structures ### Option A: They Don't Solve It Cleanly - The evidence against Danny is circumstantial, but so is the evidence for Victor - They clear Danny enough that Kovač stops pursuing him, but the case goes cold - They'll never know for sure who killed Webb - The uncertainty mirrors their relationship uncertainty - More noir: not everything is knowable ### Option B: Danny Did It (Sort Of) - Danny didn't murder Webb, but he was blackmailing him - Miles has to decide whether to help him anyway - They frame Victor (who's guilty of something else) to protect Danny - Ending is them living with what they've done - More morally complex, darker ### Option C: Miles Is More Complicit - Miles was more involved in the past crime than he admits to himself - He left Danny because he was scared of getting caught, not just guilt - The story is him confronting his own self-deception - Danny has been protecting Miles all along - Inverts the expected dynamic ### Option D: No Murder Mystery - Someone's threatening to expose their past crimes - It's about dealing with consequences, not solving a puzzle - More character-focused, less plot-mechanical - The "mystery" is emotional: what really happened between them ## Alternative Romance Structures ### Option A: They Sleep Together Immediately - Chapter 1 or 2, before they've resolved anything - It complicates rather than resolves - Spend the rest of the story dealing with it - More realistic for exes with unfinished business ### Option B: They Don't
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention ## Core Concept A queer neo-noir romance about a washed-up private investigator and the con artist ex-boyfriend who may or may not have killed someone—a story less about solving a murder than about two morally compromised men deciding whether to save each other or themselves. ## Narrative Commitment: Noir First, Romance Second Rather than splitting the difference between genres, this leans into noir's moral ambiguity and fatalism while letting romance be complicated, possibly unhealthy, and definitely unresolved. The question isn't "will they end up together" but "should they, and will they anyway?" ## The Central Complication Danny was blackmailing Marcus Webb. He didn't kill him, but he's guilty of a crime and lies to Miles about it. Miles discovers this midway through and has to decide whether to protect Danny anyway. The murder solution is ambiguous—probably Victor, maybe someone else, definitely not provable. The real story is Miles choosing Danny despite knowing he hasn't changed, and living with that choice. ## Narrative Voice & Style - **First person, past tense, but close to the events**—Miles is telling this story maybe a week or month later, not years. Close enough that he's not sure he made the right choice. Uncertainty bleeds through. - **Unreliable about himself**—Miles judges Danny harshly while excusing his own complicity. The reader should see what Miles won't admit. - **Sparse prose, loaded silences**—More happens in what isn't said. Physical details over emotional explanation. - **Inconsistent chapter lengths and focus**—Some chapters are plot-heavy, some are just two people in a room talking, reflecting actual story priorities rather than mechanical balance. - **Opening line**: "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas." Period. Full stop. Let it breathe before we see him. ## Setting **Unnamed Pacific Northwest city, current day**: Rain, but not every scene. Winter, dark by 4pm. Specific locations: The Lighthouse (dive bar, cash-only, dyke night on Thursdays), Miles's studio apartment in a converted building, the wealthy neighborhood where Webb lived (incongruous with Miles and Danny's world), cheap motels, all-night diners. The city is real, not atmospheric set-dressing. ## Characters **Miles Chen (Narrator, 35)**: - Ex-PI, now bartends at The Lighthouse (three years, not five) - Quit drinking but replaced it with righteous anger and self-denial - Tells himself he left Danny for moral reasons; really he was scared of getting caught and needed someone to blame - Second-generation Chinese-American, complicated relationship with his family (not explored in detail, just present) - Still in love with Danny in a way that feels like a chronic illness **Danny Torres (33)**: - Career criminal—blackmail, grifting, some drug dealing - Genuinely charismatic and funny, not performatively damaged - Hasn't tried to change because he doesn't see the point - Was blackmailing Webb; lies about it; gets caught lying - Loves Miles but resents his moral superiority - Smokes constantly (American Spirits, yellow pack) **Supporting Characters** (less functional, more present): - **Lydia**: Lighthouse owner, 50s, butch, has her own problems (financial trouble with the bar, ex-wife drama). Protective of Miles but not a perfect moral voice—she's made her own compromises. - **Detective Sarah Kovač**: Bored, overworked, thinks Danny probably did it but doesn't care enough to try that hard. Not antagonistic, just realistic about what homicide cops actually do. - **Victor Chen**: Miles's cousin, recently released, angry. May or may not be the killer—we never know for sure. - **Marcus Webb**: Dead before the story starts, but present in photos, in how people talk about him. Closeted city councilman type, was being blackmailed by Danny, had other enemies. ## Plot Structure: Messier Causation The murder happened. Danny was involved with Webb (sexually and as his blackmailer). Danny didn't kill him but knows he looks guilty. He comes to Miles. They investigate but everything's circumstantial. Victor is suspicious but so are Webb's political enemies. The evidence points multiple directions. Danny's lie about the blackmail is discovered around Chapter 5. Miles helps him anyway, partly for love, partly because he's implicated too now. They do something morally questionable to shift suspicion away from Danny. It works, sort of. Kovač moves on to other cases. They're in the clear legally but not morally. ## Romance Structure: Non-Linear and Unresolved They sleep together in Chapter 3—too early, for the wrong reasons, because they can't help it. It makes everything more complicated. The sex is good but doesn't fix anything. They're physically reconnected but emotionally at odds through the middle chapters. Miles discovers Danny lied. They have a real rupture. In the end, Miles chooses him anyway, but the story doesn't promise they'll be happy or healthy together. Final image is ambiguous—together for now, but noir doesn't promise forever. ## Themes - Self-deception and who we pretend to be - Complicity (Miles thinks he's better than Danny; he's not) - Queer life in straight-passing spaces (Webb's closet, respectability politics) - Whether love justifies protecting someone who's guilty - The past doesn't explain everything (not all damage comes from trauma) ## What I'm Aiming For - Moral ambiguity that doesn't resolve - A romance that's genuinely complicated (not miscommunication, but real issues) - Noir that's dark in content, not just aesthetic - Queer specificity (how they move through the world, community dynamics, Webb's closet as more than symbol) - Scenes that exist for character/mood, not just plot - Ending that doesn't tie everything up - Miles as unreliable narrator about his own goodness - Physical, visceral writing (how things feel, taste, smell) - Humor in dark places (Danny's gallows jokes, bar banter) ## What I'm Avoiding - Perfect plot symmetry - Both characters growing equally - The murder solution that explains everything - Romance as healing/redemption - Queer trauma porn (but also not sanitized) - Every scene serving multiple functions - Explicit emotional articulation - A clear "they'll be okay" ending - Making Danny too sympathetic (he's genuinely a criminal) - Making Miles too righteous (he's a hypocrite) ## Ending Miles and Danny do something illegal to protect Danny—maybe plant evidence on Victor, maybe just create reasonable doubt through questionable means. It works well enough. Kovač stops investigating actively. But Miles knows Danny lied to him, knows he'll probably lie again, knows this is who Danny is. He chooses him anyway. Not because Danny changed. Not because love conquers all. Because Miles can't let him go, and maybe that's enough, or maybe it's tragic. The final scene: them in Miles's apartment, Danny smoking out the window, Miles watching him and thinking about all the times he'll probably have to make this choice again. No rain stopping. No new beginning. Just: this is what it is. # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1: "Smoke" (~1000 words) **Opening**: "He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas." Then: Miles sees Danny outside The Lighthouse at closing time (2am). Three years since they've spoken. Immediate atmosphere: rain, empty street, the shock of seeing him. Very little exposition—trust the reader. Danny says "I need help" and Miles says "No" but they both know he will. Brief flashes of sense memory (how Danny smells like tobacco and something else, how he stands too close). Danny: "Someone's dead and they think I did it." Miles doesn't invite him in, but he doesn't walk away. Chapter ends with them in Miles's apartment, Danny dripping rainwater on the floor, lighting a cigarette Miles doesn't ask him not to smoke. **Focus**: Atmosphere, immediate physical chemistry/tension, character establishment through action/detail rather than explanation. No backstory yet. ## Chapter 2: "The Dead Man" (~1200 words) Miles makes coffee, neither of them sleeps. Danny explains: Marcus Webb, city councilman (planning commission, smalltime corruption), found shot in his home office four days ago. Danny was sleeping with him casually. Security footage shows Danny leaving the building an hour before estimated time of death. Police want him for questioning; he ran instead (which looks guilty). Miles asks the obvious questions. Danny's answers are plausible but slippery. Miles's narration reveals he's watching for tells—Danny touches his neck when he lies, lights cigarettes off each other when he's anxious. But Miles isn't sure if he's seeing lies or just expecting them. They look at news coverage on Miles's laptop, sitting on the couch. Too close. Danny falls asleep mid-sentence, exhausted. Miles watches him sleep and thinks about the last time (no details yet, just: "the last time I watched him sleep, I was planning how to leave"). **Focus**: Exposition through dialogue, Miles's investigative instincts reactivating, physical proximity, the question of whether Danny's telling the truth. Slightly longer chapter because setup is necessary. ## Chapter 3: "The Lighthouse" (~900 words) Morning. Danny's gone—left a note: "had to get something, back tonight." Miles is irrationally angry about this. Goes to work at The Lighthouse for the lunch shift. Lydia immediately knows something's wrong, pulls him into the office. Miles tells her Danny's back. Lydia: "Jesus, Miles." But she doesn't say don't help him. She says "Be careful," which Miles resents because it implies he's not in control. Bar scenes: lunch crowd, regulars, the texture of Miles's current life. He's good at this job. He likes the routine. A customer asks about his weekend and he lies smoothly—realizes he's better at lying than he pretends. Danny shows up at the bar late afternoon. They talk about next steps—Miles knows someone at the city records office, can get Webb's financials. Danny's funny, charming the daytime regulars. Lydia watches from across the bar, unreadable. After closing, in the stockroom, Danny kisses Miles. Miles kisses back. They have sex against the wall among beer kegs and liquor boxes. It's urgent, not romantic. After, Danny lights a cigarette and says "I missed you." Miles doesn't say it back. **Focus**: Miles's current world, Lydia as real person with her own concerns, the sex happening too early and for complicated reasons, noir setting (the bar) as real workplace. ## Chapter 4: "What He Didn't Say" (~1000 words) The next day. Miles calls in sick to the bar (rare enough that Lydia texts him: "you ok?"). He and Danny go to see Miles's contact—Jenn, records clerk, owes Miles a favor from his PI days. She pulls Webb's property records, financial filings. Webb was in debt. Recent large cash deposits (being paid off for something? Or paying someone off?). Connection to a development deal in the old industrial district—Victor's name appears as a minor investor who got bought out. Victor. Miles hasn't thought about his cousin in years, didn't know he was out of prison. Danny asks about him. Miles is evasive—says it's complicated, family shit. They go to a diner (specific: vinyl booths, Greek owner who's been there forty years, open 24 hours). Over coffee and pie, Danny tells a story about a job he pulled last year—funny, self-deprecating, skillful. Miles laughs despite himself. Then: "Why'd you really come to me?" Danny: "You're the only one I trust." Miles doesn't believe him, but wants to. Danny goes to the bathroom. His phone buzzes on the table. Text preview: "you get the rest when—" Miles doesn't look further. But he could have. **Focus**: Investigation, world-building through specific details, their dynamic (easier after sex but not resolved), the first real hint Danny's not telling everything, Miles's choice not to look at the phone (complicity). ## Chapter 5: "Victor" (~1100 words) They find Victor working at an auto shop in the industrial district—the same area as Webb's development deal. Miles hasn't seen him since before prison (seven years). Victor's changed: harder, tattooed, cold. He's not surprised to see Miles. Confrontation: Victor says he heard about Webb. Says he's not sorry the guy's dead—Webb fucked him on the development deal, same way Miles fucked him back then. Miles tries to explain (we get backstory here: Miles and Danny exposed Victor's embezzling to a mark, which spiraled, Victor went to prison). Victor: "You ruined my life and pretended it was justice." Danny steps in, smooth-talks, tries to find out if Victor had contact with Webb recently. Victor tells him to fuck off. To Miles: "You look like shit. Guess trying to be good didn't work out." After, in the car, Miles is shaken. Danny: "He could have done it." Miles: "A lot of people could have done it." Danny: "But you think I did." Miles: "Did you?" Danny: "No." The silence after. Danny lights a cigarette. Miles drives. That night, Miles can't sleep. He looks through Danny's phone while Danny's in the shower. Finds texts about Webb—Danny was blackmailing him. Financial arrangement, threats, Webb trying to negotiate. The last message: the day before Webb died. Danny comes out, sees Miles with the phone. **Focus**: Confronting the past (Victor as what Miles's righteousness actually caused), the discovery of Danny's lie, rupture. Longer chapter because it's the turn. ## Chapter 6: "Guilty" (~800 words) The fight. Danny admits it—he was blackmailing Webb over his closeted status and financial irregularities. Started six months ago. He swears he didn't kill him, that someone else must have, that he's a thief not a murderer. Miles: "You lied to me." Danny: "You would've turned me away." Miles: "Yes." But Miles doesn't tell him to leave. That's the thing. He should, and he doesn't. Danny: "Why are you still here?" Miles doesn't answer because he doesn't know, or doesn't want to say. They sit in silence. Danny smokes. Miles drinks coffee, wishes it were whiskey, doesn't pour one. Finally, Miles: "I'm not going to turn you in." Danny: "Why?" Miles: "Because I'm not who I pretend to be either." Admission: Miles didn't leave Danny three years ago because of morals. He left because he was scared. Because Victor went to prison and Miles realized he could too. Because it was easier to blame Danny for being what they both were. Danny: "So what now?" Miles: "Now I decide if I'm helping you or myself." **Focus**: Emotional confrontation, shorter because it's just them in a room, Miles's self-deception cracking, the decision to continue despite everything. Not reconciliation—acceptance. ## Chapter 7: "Evidence" (~1100 words) They keep investigating, but it's different now. Transactional, careful. They interview one of Webb's political enemies (a city council rival). They stake out Victor's apartment. Everything's circumstantial. Victor had motive and means. So did the rival. So did Danny. Detective Kovač calls Miles—wants to talk about Danny. Miles meets her at a coffee shop. She's tired, has three other open cases, cares but not enough to work miracles. She knows Danny was blackmailing Webb (found evidence). Says if Danny comes in voluntarily, maybe they can work something out. If he runs, she'll find him eventually.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Miles Chen ## Background & Personality Miles is 35, born and raised in the Seattle suburbs to parents who immigrated from Taiwan in the 80s. He has an older sister (Jessica, a dentist, married, two kids) who represents everything he's not—stable, successful, straight. His parents are politely disappointed in him. They don't ask about his personal life anymore. He hasn't brought anyone to a family dinner in five years. His mother still introduces him as "working in hospitality" rather than saying he's a bartender. He got a criminology degree he's never used officially, became a PI at 26 through a correspondence course and hustle. Was good at it—the research part, the surveillance, piecing together patterns. Bad at the ethical lines. Started drinking regularly around 28, heavily by 30. Met Danny when Danny hired him to do background on a mark, then hired him again, then they were working together, then they were fucking, then Miles couldn't tell where one ended and the other began. Quit drinking at 32 after a blackout where he woke up in his car outside his parents' house with no memory of driving there. Got sober through AA but stopped going to meetings after six months because he hated the God stuff and the hugging. Now he white-knuckles it with coffee and self-righteousness. **Flaws**: Self-righteous, judgmental (especially of Danny), substitutes anger for dealing with feelings, believes his own bullshit about why he left Danny, emotionally withholding, holds grudges, thinks not drinking makes him morally superior, terrible at asking for help. **Idiosyncrasies**: - Drinks coffee constantly, black, from the same chipped mug (blue, says "World's Okayest Brother"—Jessica gave it to him as a joke) - Reads crime novels obsessively, even though they're about his actual life—finds it comforting when fictional detectives solve things - Keeps his apartment obsessively neat (controlling the space since he can't control much else) - Has a tell when he's lying—he touches his watch (doesn't wear one anymore, still touches his wrist) - Learned to cook exactly five meals after getting sober, rotates through them - Saves newspaper crosswords but never finishes them, they pile up on his coffee table - Still has Danny's leather jacket in his closet, won't admit why he kept it **Specific memories that shaped him**: - Age 12: His dad asking him why he couldn't be more like Jessica, meaning it kindly, it landing like a stone - Age 23: First time he lied on a PI case and it worked—the little thrill that scared him - Age 29: Danny laughing at something Miles said, that specific laugh Danny only did when he was surprised into joy, Miles thinking "oh no" - Age 32: Three days sober, shaking so hard he couldn't hold a glass, calling his sister who came and didn't ask questions ## Physicality 5'10", lean in a wiry way, not muscular. Looks good in the dark, tired in daylight. Black hair he cuts himself (badly—there's always one section shorter than the others). Wears glasses (black frames, functional not stylish) for reading but takes them off around people. Dark eyes that he uses to watch people, notice things—it's an investigator's stare, slightly uncomfortable if you're on the receiving end. Dresses like someone who stopped caring but has baseline competence: jeans, henley shirts, one good leather jacket (not Danny's), work boots. Everything's clean but worn. Moves efficiently, doesn't take up much space. Has anxious hands—always needs something to do (washing glasses, scrolling his phone, flipping his keyring). Behind the bar he's fluid, competent, can carry three pints and remember four orders. In the rest of his life he's more awkward—stands too stiffly, doesn't know what to do at parties, terrible at small talk unless he's serving you a drink. ## Motives, Allegiances & Relationships **What he wants**: To believe he's good. To not want Danny anymore. To go back to the quiet life he's built and feel satisfied by it. (He won't admit: he wants Danny, he wants the chaos, he's bored out of his skull.) **What he fears**: Drinking again. Becoming his parents' disappointment confirmed. Admitting he left Danny to save himself, not for moral reasons. That he's not actually any better than he was. **Allegiances**: - Himself first (though he'd deny it) - Lydia, who gave him the bar job when no one else would - Some abstract concept of justice that's mostly about ego - Danny, despite everything, always Danny **Relationships**: - **Danny**: Still in love, mostly resentment about that fact, keeps trying to make it Danny's fault - **Lydia**: Genuine friendship but he doesn't fully open up; respects her; fears her judgment - **His family**: Dutiful but distant; calls his mom every Sunday and lies about his week; loves his sister's kids from afar - **Bar regulars**: Performs friendliness, is good at surface-level rapport, doesn't let anyone close ## Voice Examples **Internal monologue**: - *"Danny looked at me like I was the answer to a question he hadn't asked yet, and I wanted to tell him I was fresh out of answers. Had been for three years. But instead I said 'Coffee?' because that's what you do when your ex shows up soaking wet and probably guilty."* - *"Lydia says I make things harder than they need to be. She's right, but knowing that doesn't help. I know a lot of things that don't help."* - *"I wasn't going to look at his phone. I'm not that person. Except I was that person for years, and not being him anymore is just a decision I make every day, and some days I'm tired of deciding."* **Dialogue**: - "You want me to believe you didn't kill him? Fine. I believe lots of things that aren't true." - "I don't drink anymore. It's not a big deal, you don't have to—it's just a thing now." - "Victor went to prison because he was embezzling, not because we exposed him. We just... expedited the process." # Danny Torres ## Background & Personality Danny is 33, grew up in Southern California (Riverside County), raised by his grandmother after his mom went to prison when he was eight (drug charges, in and out his whole childhood). Never knew his dad. His grandmother died when he was 19, and he's been on his own since—no other family he claims. Never finished college (went for a year on financial aid, studied theater, dropped out when the money ran out). Turns out he didn't need the degree—he was already better at performing than anyone in his classes. Started running small cons at 20, got good at it, never saw a reason to stop. Has been arrested three times: once at 21 (shoplifting, charges dropped), once at 25 (fraud, pleaded down, probation), once at 28 (assault, bar fight, the other guy didn't press charges). Has never done serious time, is terrified of prison in a way he'd never admit. Met Miles seven years ago when he needed someone investigated for a con. Miles was thorough, didn't ask too many questions, had these eyes that tried to look hard but weren't. Danny hired him again. Then again. Then they were splitting profits. Then they were sleeping together. Then Miles left and Danny told himself it was fine, except it wasn't, but you can't con yourself (actually you can, Danny's just not good at it). **Flaws**: Lies reflexively even when truth would work better, self-destructive, doesn't believe he deserves good things so sabotages them first, commitment-phobic, uses charm to avoid real connection, can't admit fear or vulnerability, tends to run when things get hard. **Idiosyncrasies**: - Smokes American Spirits (yellow pack) because they burn slower—always has a lighter in his left pocket, cigarettes in his right - Wears rings (three: silver, one on right thumb, two on left hand) that he plays with when thinking - Learned card tricks from his grandmother, still practices, does them unconsciously when his hands are idle - Excellent cook (learned from abuela) but never does it because it makes him melancholy - Bilingual but his Spanish is informal, grandma-Spanish, he's self-conscious about it - Keeps burner phones but always forgets to actually use them, ends up texting from his real phone - Sleeps on his stomach, sprawled like he's trying to take up as much space as possible - Has a tell when he's lying: touches his neck, right side, just below his ear **Specific memories that shaped him**: - Age 8: Visiting his mom in jail, her telling him to be good, him realizing she was never getting out, that "be good" just meant "don't be like me" - Age 17: His grandmother catching him stealing from her purse, her not saying anything, just looking sad, which was worse - Age 24: Pulling off his first major con, the rush of it, thinking "I'm good at something" - Age 30: Waking up next to Miles, watching him sleep, thinking "I should leave before I fuck this up," staying anyway, fucking it up anyway (except it was Miles who left) ## Physicality 5'11", broader in the shoulders than Miles, moves like he's comfortable in his body. Beautiful in a way that's almost unfair—sharp cheekbones, full mouth, dark eyes that crinkle when he smiles (which is often). Brown skin that tans darker in summer. Black hair worn longer, falls in his eyes, he pushes it back constantly (the gesture is deliberate, he knows it's attractive). Dresses better than he can afford—thrift store finds that look expensive, good eye for fit. Leather jacket (brown, worn soft), dark jeans, boots, simple t-shirts. Always looks slightly underdressed for the weather (never wears a real coat, even in winter). Silver rings catch light when he gestures, and he gestures a lot. Expressive face—hard to keep a poker face except when conning, then he can go completely blank. Smiles easily, touches people when he talks (hand on your arm, shoulder, back), takes up space unselfconsciously. Smokes like it's choreographed: the pack-tap, the lighter flick, the exhale. Miles thinks he practiced it in a mirror once; he's probably right. ## Motives, Allegiances & Relationships **What he wants**: To not be scared all the time. Miles, but without having to change who he is. Money—not wealth, just enough to stop hustling. To believe he's not his mother (too late, he already doesn't). **What he fears**: Prison. Being alone. That Miles sees who he really is and left because of it. Ending up like his mom—locked up, forgotten, a cautionary tale. **Allegiances**: - Himself (survival mode, always) - Miles (even when Miles was gone, even when it would be smarter not to) - His grandmother's memory (he's failed her, but her voice still asks him to be good) - Nobody else, really **Relationships**: - **Miles**: In love in a way that feels like a weakness; resentful that Miles left and got to be the righteous one; knows he's toxic for Miles and hates himself for coming back - **Marcus Webb**: Started as a mark, became something almost like affection (Webb was lonely, Danny felt bad for him, which made bilking him easier and worse) - **Various marks/contacts**: Transactional relationships; Danny's charming and people like him, but he doesn't let anyone know him - **His past**: Haunted by his grandmother, by his mother, by every version of himself that tried to be good and failed ## Voice Examples **Dialogue**: - "You want the truth? Okay. I was blackmailing him. I'm a blackmailer, Miles. Among other things. You knew that when you fucked me, so don't look at me like I've disappointed you." - "I missed you. I know I'm not supposed to say that. Supposed to play it cool, act like the last three years were fine, but fuck it—I missed you every single day." - "You left because you wanted to be good. I get it. I just wish you'd admitted you couldn't be good and be with me. Would've been honest, at least." - "I didn't kill him. I'm a lot of things, but I'm not that. Not yet." **Internal thoughts (if we had his POV)**: - *"Miles looks at me like I'm a crime scene he's trying to solve. Maybe I am."* - *"I should tell him the truth. That's what you do when you love someone, right? Except every time I've told the truth, I've lost something."* # Lydia Cross ## Background & Personality Lydia is 52, Seattle native (rare). Grew up working-class, daughter of a union machinist and a nurse. Came out at 19 in 1991, got thrown out, lived on friends' couches in the Capitol Hill scene. Worked bar jobs through her twenties and thirties, saved enough to buy The Lighthouse eight years ago (her name's on a twenty-year mortgage she'll probably die paying). Was married (domestic partnership, then legal marriage) to a woman named Patricia for twelve years. Divorced four years ago—not dramatic, just grew apart, wanted different things. Patricia wanted to move to Portland and open a B&B; Lydia couldn't leave the bar. They're civil, exchange Christmas cards, don't talk otherwise. Hired Miles three years ago when he showed up looking rough, asking if she needed help.
