Ellis different—more open. They talk easily. Rhys invites Ellis to walk. They go to the beach (it's cold, grey, not romantic). Walk and talk—about childhoods, choices, regrets. Rhys admits he's not sure he likes his life. Ellis admits they're scared they made a mistake (moving here, the shop failing). Honesty that's uncomfortable. Back at the shop, they kiss—it's a bit awkward, then good. Ellis pulls back: "You're still leaving." Rhys: "I know." They look at each other. Ellis: "Come upstairs." They do. (Implication, not detail.) **Key elements:** - Ellis clearing the deck with Meredith (not dramatically, just reality) - Gemma's texts—Rhys's other life intruding - Small town awareness (mum knows) - Beach walk: honest conversation, not neat revelations - Both admitting unhappiness/uncertainty - Kiss that's real—awkward then good - Sleeping together as a choice made with eyes open (this won't be simple) ## Chapter 6: "Morning" (~1000 words) **Setting:** Ellis's flat above the shop, morning; then bookshop **Action:** Morning after. Not awkward but not perfect either—Ellis's flat is cold, small, a bit shabby. They make breakfast together (limited groceries). Domestic, nice. Rhys's phone keeps buzzing (he ignores it). Talk about logistics: Rhys flies back to London in four days. Ellis: "So this is..." Rhys: "I don't know." Honest. They're in the shop when a couple comes in—tourists—recognize Rhys, ask for photos. Rhys accommodates (nice, professional) but it breaks the bubble. After they leave, buying nothing, Ellis quiet. Rhys: "Sorry." Ellis: "For what?" Rhys: "That." Ellis: "It's your life." Rhys: "Is that a problem?" Ellis: "I don't know yet." They work in the shop together—back to shelving, talking about small things. Comfortable but underscored with uncertainty. A local (Gareth, owns the pub) comes in, friendly with Ellis, curious about Rhys. After he leaves: Ellis explains they've been good to them here, community matters. Rhys feels the weight—this is Ellis's life, he's disrupting it. Evening: they close up, cook dinner in the flat (simple, pasta maybe). Rhys: "I want more time." Ellis: "But you don't have it." Neither does. They spend the night together anyway. **Key elements:** - Morning that's real—cold flat, mundane breakfast - Rhys's phone (the other life calling) - Photo request—intrusion, Ellis sees the reality - Community ties—Ellis has built something - Rhys feeling like a disruption - Wanting more time but time is finite - Choosing the present despite no future certainty ## Chapter 7: "Famous" (~1000 words) **Setting:** Bookshop and around town, over two days **Action:** Next two days, they're almost playing house—Rhys in the shop, helping, talking, sleeping upstairs. But cracks show: Rhys's phone constantly going off (his agent, publicist, work stuff). He takes a call—Ellis overhears him being "Rhys Morgan, Movie Star" voice. Ellis pulls back emotionally. A tabloid piece appears online: "Rhys Morgan's Secret Welsh Love Nest"—photos of him outside the shop. Ellis sees it (a customer shows them, excited). Ellis feels exposed, their privacy invaded. Confronts Rhys: "Is this what it's like?" Rhys: "Sometimes. I'm sorry." Ellis: "I didn't sign up for this." Rhys: "I know. I didn't ask you to." Argument—not loud, but real. Ellis feeling their carefully built peace threatene
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Rhys Morgan ## Background & Personality **Age:** 38 **Background:** Grew up in Pennaeth, only child. Father was a PE teacher, mother worked at the council offices. Solid, working-class Welsh upbringing. Got into acting almost by accident—school drama teacher pushed him into it, he was good at it, liked the attention. Went to drama school in London (the only one from Pennaeth to do so), felt like an imposter the whole time. Early career was theatre, struggling, then got a break in a BBC period drama at 26. That led to film work. Now he's "that Welsh actor"—recognizable, works steadily, gets good parts, makes good money, but isn't quite A-list. Has done one superhero franchise film (supporting role), several period dramas, a few prestige indies. **Personality contradictions:** Genuinely loves acting when he's doing it, but hates everything around it. Craves validation but resents needing it. Charming but exhausting—even he knows it. Generous (will pick up the bill, buy rounds) but it's partially performance. Nostalgic about Wales but hasn't been back properly in two years. Says he values authenticity but performs constantly. **Idiosyncrasies:** - Touches his hair when nervous (used to be a thick curl, now he's self-conscious about thinning) - Does impressions mid-conversation without announcing them—just slips into voices - Orders the same thing at every pub (bitter, specific brand if they have it) - Sleeps terribly, always has. Takes melatonin, scrolls phone at 3am - Collects vinyl but never plays it (has an expensive record player in his London flat, unopened records) - Says "you know what I mean?" constantly, seeking agreement - His Welsh accent softened for work but returns with certain words (anything with 'll', 'home', 'mam') **Flaws (the real ones):** - Interrupts people to make the conversation about him - Humble-brags: "God, I was so bad in that film, wasn't I? The director had to do so many takes with me." (Waiting for: "No, you were brilliant!") - Name-drops unconsciously: "When I was working with Judi—Dench, sorry—she said..." - Checks his phone constantly, even mid-conversation - Goes into "actor mode" when uncomfortable—tells rehearsed anecdotes - Deeply insecure about aging (the grey, the softness around his middle, losing roles to younger actors) - Has never had a relationship last more than eight months - Financially comfortable but weird about it (feels guilty, overcompensates) - Drinks a bit too much when anxious **Specific examples:** - Still has his Pennaeth accent when saying his mum's name: "Mam" (not "Mum") - Dyes the grey at his temples for auditions but it's growing out now (hasn't worked in six weeks) - Wears expensive casual clothes that look effortless but cost £300 (trying to look like he's not trying) - Has a scar through his left eyebrow from falling off a bike at age 12 - Went vegetarian two years ago for a role, kept it up, but cheats with bacon - Texts in complete sentences with proper punctuation (actor training) ## Physicality **Appearance:** 6'1", used to be lean, now has what he calls "dad bod" (he's not a dad, he's just 38 and eats craft services). Dark hair with grey coming through at the temples and scattered through. Brown eyes, expressive (trained). Strong Welsh features—defined jaw, good cheekbones, but his face is starting to show wear (fine lines, the beginning of jowls he obsesses over). Has put on maybe 15 pounds in the last year, carries it in his stomach and face. Hands are nice—long fingers, expressive. Dresses in expensive casual: good jeans, soft sweaters, boots that look worn but weren't cheap. **Physicality & Expression:** Moves like someone aware they might be watched—there's a performance quality even to casual gestures. Trained posture (drama school, voice work). Gestures a lot when talking, uses hands. Touches people when talking to them (arm, shoulder) in a way that seems warm but is also Establishing Connection. Smiles easily, often. Laughs loudly. Takes up space. But when he's genuinely nervous or upset, he shrinks—hunches shoulders, crosses arms, makes himself smaller. Runs his hand through his hair (the tell). Eye contact that's sometimes too intense (actor training) then looks away when actually vulnerable. ## Motives, Allegiances, Relationships **What he wants (thinks he wants):** To be taken seriously as an actor. To be recognized but not bothered. To feel like himself, whoever that is. To stop feeling lonely. **What he actually wants:** To matter to someone. To not have to perform. To figure out if he made the right choices leaving Pennaeth, or if he's wasted 20 years becoming someone he doesn't like. **Current relationships:** - **His mum, Eirlys:** Loves her, visits sporadically, feels guilty about it. She's proud of him but he suspects she doesn't really understand his life. She's 67, still works part-time, has her own life. He's here for her 68th birthday (two weeks in Pennaeth). She asks when he's going to settle down. He deflects. - **Gemma Constantine (ex-girlfriend, actress):** They dated on-and-off for two years, broke up six months ago, still text constantly. It's comfortable, familiar, a bit toxic. Neither can quite let go. She's the only person who understands his life. They probably shouldn't get back together but might. - **Matt (agent):** Calls twice a day. Rhys answers half the time. Matt is good at his job, sees Rhys as a commodity. Rhys knows this, resents it, needs it. - **School friends from Pennaeth:** Lost touch with most. Tom married Sioned, has three kids, still lives here. They had pints when Rhys visited two years ago, ran out of things to say after 20 minutes. **Why he's in Pennaeth:** Mam's birthday. Trying to be a good son. Also avoiding London (between projects, feeling unmoored). Paparazzi found him because Gemma posted an Instagram story that hinted at his location (she does this, he knows she does this, he hasn't told her to stop). ## Voice Experiments **Flavour dialogue:** "Right, so there I was—this is mad, actually—we're shooting this scene in Dubrovnik, boiling hot, I'm in full costume, and Colin—Firth, this was—he just looks at me and says... well, I can't tell you what he said, but it was brilliant. You know what I mean? Just one of those moments where you think, 'This is why I do this.' Does that make sense?" "Mam's doing my head in, if I'm honest. She's got the church ladies over every afternoon, all talking about me like I'm not there. 'Ooh, Rhys, what's it like working with so-and-so?' Just... I love her, I do, but Christ." "I'm not famous famous. I mean, I'm not... you know. I can go to Tesco most days. It's fine. It's totally fine." "You really don't watch films? Like, at all? That's... God, that must be nice, actually." **Internal monologue:** *She hasn't asked a single question about my work. Not one. Is that refreshing or insulting? Both? She's looking at me like I'm... what, just some bloke who wandered in wet. Which I am. Which is good. So why am I desperate to tell her about the BAFTA nomination?* *Don't check your phone. Don't check your phone. She's talking, listen. Shit, what did she just say? Something about books. I used to read. When? Years ago. I should read more. I'll tell her that—people like it when you admit things like that. No, that's... fuck, I'm doing it again. Just talk. Just be normal.* # Ellis Carter ## Background & Personality **Age:** 35 **Background:** Grew up in Reading, middle-class, both parents teachers (English and History). Academic family, books everywhere, expectations of university and career. Went to Durham, read English Lit, got a first. Moved to London at 22 for publishing—worked at a mid-size house as an editor. Was good at it, climbed to senior editor by 30. Then: panic attacks, insomnia, two months of sick leave, resignation (theirs, before they could be pushed). Breakdown was about overwork but also about realizing they were living a life that felt performed, not chosen. Therapist said they needed a change. They inherited £80k when grandmother died (six months after the breakdown). Saw the listing for The Longhand in Pennaeth online at 2am during insomnia. Bought it. Moved three months later. Has been here three years. No regrets. Some regrets. Mostly no regrets. **Personality contradictions:** Values authenticity but is deeply guarded. Scornful of celebrity culture but secretly curious. Says they love the quiet life but gets lonely. Intellectually confident, emotionally scared. Projects calm but has anxiety that wakes them at 4am. Generous with book recommendations, stingy with personal information. **Idiosyncrasies:** - Organizes books in idiosyncratic ways (not alphabetical, not by genre—by what they call "feeling") - Drinks tea constantly, specific about it (loose leaf, timer, proper temperature) - Wears reading glasses for close work, is vain about them, takes them off when talking to people - Has a fountain pen they use for accounts (gift from uni friend, one of the few things from London they kept) - Listens to Radio 4 while working (Today Programme, Book Club, the shipping forecast) - Stands with arms crossed when uncomfortable (knows they do this, can't stop) - Welsh is functional but accented (they're learning, takes a class in Cardigan on Thursdays) **Flaws (the real ones):** - Pretentious about books—will say things like "I don't read contemporary fiction much" (do read it, guilty about it) - Conflict-avoidant to a fault—let things with Meredith drag on because ending it felt hard - Drinks wine alone most nights (half a bottle, sometimes more, tells themselves it's fine) - Judgmental about people who live "unexamined lives" (defensive projection) - Uses books as shields—references them to avoid being direct - Proud of not having a TV but it's performative (watches things on laptop) - Has ghosted London friends who tried to stay in touch - Financially anxious (the shop isn't making enough, the inheritance is dwindling, they don't acknowledge this) - Attracted to unavailable people (Rhys fits the pattern) **Specific examples:** - The shop's heating is broken, they wear fingerless gloves and a cardigan inside all winter, haven't called the repair person because it costs money - Still has a box from London they haven't unpacked (under the bed, three years later) - Keeps a bottle of good whisky on the shelf that they never drink (it was their father's, he's still alive, they're not speaking much) - Meal preps poorly—eats toast for dinner, then a block of cheese, then three biscuits - Writes book reviews for a blog under a pseudonym (doesn't tell people this) - Has a cat, Tolstoy, who's antisocial (they got him from the shelter two years ago, he barely tolerates them) ## Physicality **Appearance:** 5'8", slim build, androgynous presentation. Short dark hair, usually pushed back from face (needs a cut, keeps meaning to). Pale—doesn't get much sun despite living at the coast. Grey-green eyes behind wire-frame glasses (takes them off when not reading, squints). Fine features, what their mother calls "interesting looking" (not conventionally attractive, but striking). Hands always have paper cuts, ink stains. Dresses practically: dark jeans, button-downs, jumpers, brogues. Everything is worn-in, quality but old. Doesn't wear makeup. Has small silver hoops in ears (got them pierced at 16, small rebellion). **Physicality & Expression:** Economical with movement—doesn't gesture much, keeps hands in pockets or holds a book/mug. Good posture from years of teachers telling them to sit up. Moves quietly (creaky shop floors have taught them where to step). Makes steady eye contact when listening, looks away when talking about themselves. Smiles rarely but genuinely—it transforms their face. Laughs by exhaling through nose (small "hm" sound) more than actual laughing. Touches books constantly, unconsciously—straightening spines, running fingers along shelves. Stands with weight on one hip. Crosses arms when defensive (knows it's obvious, does it anyway).

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 1: The Bell The bell above the door hit the frame with a sharp crack instead of its usual chime—Ellis had been meaning to fix that for months—and a man stumbled in trailing rain and panic. "Shit, sorry, sorry—" He pushed the door shut behind him, breathing hard, and pressed his back against it like something was chasing him. Ellis looked up from the accounts spreadsheet that was making their head hurt. October had been dismal. September hadn't been much better. The summer tourist bump was a memory, and winter stretched ahead like a threat. "Can I help you?" The man was dripping on the floorboards. Mid-thirties, maybe older. Expensive-looking jumper going dark with rain. He ran a hand through his wet hair and attempted a smile that was probably meant to be charming. "God, sorry, I just—needed to get inside. Mental out there." It was raining, not mental. Standard Welsh autumn afternoon. Ellis waited. "Right." The man looked around, still catching his breath. "This is lovely. Really lovely. I love bookshops." He said it like he expected something back. Ellis had been doing this long enough to recognize a performance. They'd seen it with tourists who wanted to prove they were Literary People, not like those *other* tourists. "Thanks," Ellis said, and looked back at the spreadsheet. "No, really, proper bookshops like this are so rare now, aren't they? All those chains, Amazon, the whole—you know what I mean?" "Mmm." The man moved further in, tracking water. He pulled off his jacket—Barbour, naturally—and held it awkwardly. Ellis didn't offer to take it. "Been here long? The shop, I mean." "Three years." "Brilliant. That's brilliant. Must be... yeah. Doing well?" Ellis glanced up. The man was looking at the shelves with the kind of studied interest that meant he was aware of being looked at. Actor, maybe. Or just English. "Can I help you find something?" "Oh, no, just—browsing. If that's alright?" Ellis gestured vaguely at the shop. Go ahead. They needed to figure out whether they could afford to restock the fiction section before Christmas or if they were just rearranging what they had. The man moved along the nearest shelf, trailing his fingers over spines. Ellis watched him from their peripheral vision. Something familiar about him, maybe. Or maybe he just had that kind of face. Symmetrical. Put-together. "This is a great collection," the man said. "Really eclectic. Are you the owner?" "Yes." "I'm Rhys." Pause. Ellis was clearly meant to do something with that information. They looked up properly. "Ellis." "Nice to meet you, Ellis." Rhys smiled again. He had a nice smile, objectively. Probably knew it. "Have you read all of these?" "No." "Right, no, of course not. That would be—although that would be amazing, wouldn't it? I always think people who work in bookshops must be so well-read. Do you have a favorite section?" He was nervous. Ellis revised their assessment. Not performing confidence—performing through nervousness. "Poetry's upstairs." "Oh, I love poetry. I don't read enough poetry. No one does, do they?" Ellis made a noncommittal sound and returned to the spreadsheet. The numbers hadn't improved. A beat of silence. Then: "What are you reading at the moment?" Ellis sighed and took off their reading glasses. Tolstoy had been sleeping on the accounts book anyway. They picked up the paperback from beside the register. "This." Rhys came over—too quickly, eager—and looked at the cover. *The Rings of Saturn*. Sebald. His face did something complicated. "Sebald. God, yes. That's the walking one, isn't it? Through Suffolk?" "Norfolk and Suffolk." "Right, yes. I read that years ago. Or started it. I think I—" He laughed, self-deprecating. "I might not have finished it, actually. It's quite dense?" "It's worth finishing." "I'm sure. No, I'm sure it is. I just—I was doing this thing at the time, we were on location, and I kept falling asleep over it. Not because it was boring! Just the hours were—anyway." He touched his hair again. It was starting to dry, curling slightly. "Do you recommend it?" "I'm reading it." "Right. No, obviously. I meant—" The bell cracked again. They both looked. Through the window, two people with cameras were walking past, slowly, peering into shops. Rhys stepped back from the window, into the stacks. His whole body language changed—tight, alert. Ellis understood then. "Are they looking for you?" "Maybe. Probably. Yes." He glanced toward the back of the shop. "Is there a—" "Just stay away from the window." Ellis watched the photographers pass. One of them glanced in, but the shop was dim and Rhys had moved behind the Biography section. They kept walking. Rhys exhaled. "Thanks." "Are you famous then?" His face did that complicated thing again. "I'm an actor. So—sort of. Depends." "Right." "You don't recognize me?" Ellis looked at him properly. Tried to place the face. Came up with nothing. "Should I?" "No! No, that's—that's actually really nice." He laughed, and this time it sounded genuine. "Most people here... I grew up here, actually. Pennaeth. So people know me, or they know my mam, or they've seen—anyway. It's nice. That you don't." "I don't really watch films." "Everyone watches films." "I don't have a TV." "You don't have a—" He stared. "Really?" "Really." "That's very..." He trailed off. Ellis suspected he'd been about to say something rude. "Good for you." Ellis returned to the spreadsheet. The silence stretched. They heard Rhys moving, browsing, picking up books and putting them down. After a minute: "They've probably gone." "Probably." Rhys came back to the front. Put his jacket on. Looked at Ellis, then at the door, then back. "Could I—would it be alright if I stayed just a bit longer? Just to be sure?" Ellis glanced at the clock. Another hour until closing. They really needed to finish the accounts. But the man looked genuinely uncomfortable now, the performance stripped away. "If you buy something." Rhys's mouth twitched. Might have been a real smile. "Deal." He went back into the stacks. Ellis heard him moving around upstairs, floorboards creaking. They tried to focus on the numbers, but their attention kept drifting. Wondering who he was. Wondering if they should know. Wondering why they'd noticed his hands.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter effectively establishes the central dynamic requested in the prompt while demonstrating strong character work and natural dialogue. The writing is clean, purposeful, and avoids common pitfalls of amateur romance writing. The characterization is particularly successful. Rhys emerges as authentically fragile beneath his charm - his repeated attempts to connect over books, his nervous hair-touching, and his visible deflation when Ellis doesn't recognize him all ring true. The dialogue captures his neediness well through lines like "You don't recognize me?" and his over-eager "God, yes" when Ellis shows him the Sebald book. Ellis is effectively portrayed as guarded but observant, with their economical responses ("Mmm," "Right") and practical demands ("If you buy something") establishing character efficiently. The chemistry builds naturally through small moments - Ellis noticing Rhys's hands, the slight softening when Rhys asks to stay longer, the moment of genuine connection over the Sebald discussion. The awkwardness feels authentic rather than contrived, particularly in Rhys's stumbling attempts to prove his literary credentials. The setting work is understated but effective, grounding the scene in specific details (the broken bell, creaky floorboards, the accounts spreadsheet) that make the bookshop feel real. The paparazzi threat provides appropriate external pressure without overwhelming the character interaction. The dialogue maintains distinct voices throughout - Rhys's nervous chatter and validation-seeking versus Ellis's dry, minimal responses. The conversation flows naturally while advancing both plot and character development. Minor weaknesses include some slightly clunky exposition (the paragraph about Ellis's financial worries feels inserted) and the ending feels a bit abrupt. The phrase "winter stretched ahead like a threat" verges on overwrought for the otherwise understated prose style, though it doesn't severely detract. The chapter successfully fulfills both the writing prompt requirements and the model's own chapter plan, establishing the core relationship dynamic while maintaining narrative momentum. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 2: Temperance Rhys came back downstairs holding a slim volume of Mary Oliver. "Are you closed? I can go if—" "Twenty minutes." Ellis saved the spreadsheet without looking at the final number. Thinking about it wouldn't help. "Right. I'll just—" He gestured vaguely at a chair by the window, then remembered and moved to one in the back corner instead. Ellis stood, joints stiff from sitting. The shop was cold. The heating had been making an ominous rattling sound for a week, so they'd turned it off. Another problem for another day. "Do you want tea?" Rhys looked up, surprised. "Oh. Yeah, that'd be—if you're making some anyway." "I'm making some anyway." The kettle was in the back room that served as office, storage, and kitchen. Ellis filled it from the tap, set
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a significant disappointment relative to the ambitious and detailed plan laid out by the test model. What should have been a roughly 1000-word chapter exploring crucial character dynamics and plot development instead delivers fewer than 200 words that feel more like the opening paragraphs of a scene than a complete chapter. The planned chapter had clear story beats: Rhys fishing for recognition, Ellis's disinterest wounding him, the revelation of Rhys's celebrity status, Ellis's backstory emerging, and a moment of genuine connection over shared professional struggles. None of these elements appear in the delivered text. Instead, we get a brief exchange about closing time and an offer of tea before the narrative cuts off abruptly. What is present shows competent but unremarkable prose. The financial anxiety is subtly conveyed through Ellis avoiding looking at spreadsheet numbers, and practical details like the broken heating effectively establish the struggling bookshop's atmosphere. The character dynamics remain consistent - Ellis is practical and somewhat distant, Rhys is considerate but still performing (the chair positioning shows awareness of potential paparazzi). However, the dialogue is minimal and workmanlike rather than revealing character voice. There's no exploration of the "distinct voices" promised in the prompt. The scene lacks the charged undercurrent of chemistry that should be building between these characters. Most critically, this feels like an opening fragment rather than a complete dramatic unit. The writing itself avoids major technical flaws - there's no purple prose or forced metaphors - but this restraint comes at the cost of any memorable moments or emotional resonance. The prose is competent but flat, offering little to distinguish it or create engagement. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 8 Emotionally Engaging: 5 Compelling Plot: 3 Coherent: 6 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 16 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 7 Characters Consistent with Profile: 12 Followed Chapter Plan: 2 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 4

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 3: Stock Three days passed. Ellis had almost convinced themselves they weren't disappointed. Then the bell cracked and Rhys came in carrying two paper bags that smelled like grease and salt. "Morning." He said it casually, like he came in every Tuesday. Ellis was surrounded by boxes. The delivery driver had dumped them just inside the door at 8am and driven off. Twenty boxes of stock from three different wholesalers, all needing to be unpacked, checked against invoices, and shelved. Their back already hurt. "Morning." "I brought chips." Rhys held up the bags. "Bit early, I know, but I was up at the cafe and thought—well. Chips." "It's nine-thirty." "Is that too early for chips? There's no rule, is there?" He was talking too much. Nervous again. "I can go if you're—" "You can leave them on the counter." Rhys did, then stood there. He was wearing different clothes—dark jeans, a soft grey jumper that probably cost more than Ellis's weekly takings. He looked good. Ellis resented noticing. "I was going to come by anyway," Rhys said. "Not just for the chips. I mean, I was bringing chips, but I was coming regardless. My mam's got her book group over and they're all—they're lovely, but they're all asking about work and someone brought a DVD for me to sign and I just needed to—" He stopped. "Sorry. I'm talking a lot." "You are a bit." "Yeah." He touched his hair. "Can I just... be here for a while? I won't bother you." Ellis looked at the boxes, then at Rhys. "Can you lift things?" "Things?" "Books. Boxes of books." "Oh. Yes? Probably?" "Then you can stay." They worked in near silence for the first hour. Ellis showed Rhys how to unpack carefully, check the spines for damage, sort by category. He was clumsy at first—dropped one, apologized profusely—but got the rhythm of it. "Where do these go?" Rhys held up three historical biographies. "Biography. Upstairs, west wall, alphabetical by subject." "Alphabetical by—not by author?" "By subject." "That's unusual, isn't it?" Ellis shrugged. "It's my shop." Rhys smiled. Took the books upstairs. When he came back down, he'd taken his jumper off. Just a t-shirt underneath. Ellis looked away. "This is quite nice," Rhys said, opening another box. "Meditative." "It's unpacking boxes." "Yeah, but there's something—I don't know. Satisfying? When I'm filming, everything's so... there's so many people, everyone's got opinions, it's all hurry up and wait. This is just books. They're either damaged or they're not. They go on shelves. Simple." Ellis glanced at him. "Is it not satisfying? Acting?" "Sometimes." Rhys pulled out a stack of paperback fiction. "When you get a good scene, good writing, and everyone's—yeah. Sometimes it is. But a lot of it is... politics. Egos. Waiting around. Doing the same thing forty times from different angles." He paused. "That sounds ungrateful." "Does it matter if it does?" "Yes? No. I don't know." He sat back on his heels. "I shouldn't complain. It's a good job. I'm lucky." Ellis recognized that deflection. They did the same thing when people asked about the shop. *It's great. I love it.* Never mentioning the 4am anxiety, the dwindling savings. "How's the shop doing?" Rhys asked, like he'd heard the thought. "Sorry, is that rude to ask?" "It's fine. It's—" Ellis stopped. Honesty felt strange. "Harder than I thought. The summer was okay. But now..." "Yeah." They kept working. Ellis found themself relaxing into the rhythm of it, having another person there. Someone to hand boxes to, to work alongside. They hadn't realized how much silence they'd been sitting in. The bell cracked. An older woman came in, already talking. "Ellis, love, I'm after something for my granddaughter, she's into those fantasy books with the maps in—" She stopped. Stared at Rhys. "Oh my *God*." Rhys stood up quickly, smile clicking into place. "Hello." "You're Rhys Morgan! Eirlys's boy!" Mrs. Parry pressed her hand to her chest. "I didn't know you were home! Oh, we loved you in that one with the—the war one, what was it called, Gareth! Come here!" A man appeared from the Poetry section upstairs. "What's all this then?" "It's Rhys Morgan!" Ellis watched Rhys's face do something complicated. The smile stayed but his shoulders tensed. "Just visiting my mam," he said. "Trying to keep it quiet, actually, if that's—" "Of course, of course! We won't say anything, will we Gareth?" Mrs. Parry was already pulling out her phone. "Just one photo? My daughter won't believe—" "Mrs. Parry." Ellis's voice came out firmer than intended. "Did you want that book for your granddaughter?" The woman blinked. "Oh. Yes, but—" "I'll show you what I have." Ellis guided her firmly to the Young Adult section, leaving Rhys with Gareth, who was at least being quieter about his recognition. They found three fantasy novels with maps. Mrs. Parry kept glancing back at Rhys. "Is he here often then?" "No." "Just nice to see him home, isn't it? After all this time. His poor mam, she hardly sees him." Ellis made a noncommittal sound and rang up the sale. Mrs. Parry left without buying anything—"I'll think about it, love"—but did manage to get Rhys to sign her receipt. When they were gone, silence settled back. "Does that happen a lot?" Ellis asked. Rhys was still standing where they'd left him. "Yeah." "Seems exhausting." "It is." He said it quietly. Then: "Thanks. For the—you didn't have to." Ellis shrugged and went back to the boxes. At one, Rhys went out and came back with more chips, proper ones this time from the takeaway down the road. They ate sitting on the floor surrounded by empty boxes, backs against the counter. "What are you reading now?" Rhys asked. "Finish the Sebald?" "Almost. Started rereading *Middlemarch*." "God. That's the thick one, yeah? George Eliot?" "That's the one." "I should read more." Rhys said it to his chips. "I used to. At drama school, on the tube, waiting around on sets. But now I'm just—I'm tired all the time, and when I try to read I fall asleep, or I'm thinking about work, or scrolling my phone like an idiot." "That's sad." Rhys looked at her. "Yeah. It is." Ellis felt something shift. Some small opening. Rhys left at three, after helping shelve the last box. Didn't buy anything. Ellis didn't mention it.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively executes its planned function as a bridge between initial attraction and deeper connection. The writing demonstrates solid craft fundamentals with natural dialogue, believable character interactions, and restrained prose that lets the emotional undercurrents speak for themselves. The chapter successfully builds intimacy through mundane shared activity—unpacking books becomes a vehicle for the characters to relax around each other. The author wisely avoids forcing romantic tension, instead letting it emerge organically through small details like Ellis noticing when Rhys removes his jumper, then deliberately looking away. This subtlety feels authentic to both characters' established personalities. The dialogue rings true to each character's voice. Rhys's nervous over-explanation ("I was going to come by anyway. Not just for the chips") contrasts effectively with Ellis's economical responses. The conversation about acting reveals genuine vulnerability without falling into therapeutic exposition, and Rhys's admission about losing his reading habit provides a moment of honest connection that feels earned. Mrs. Parry's intrusion serves multiple functions—comic relief, plot advancement, and character revelation. Her fangirl behavior demonstrates the cost of Rhys's fame while Ellis's protective intervention shows their growing care without being heavy-handed about it. The aftermath conversation ("Does that happen a lot?" "Yeah.") achieves maximum emotional impact through minimalist dialogue. However, the chapter suffers from competent but unremarkable prose. While the writing avoids purple flourishes and forced metaphors, it also lacks distinctive voice or memorable moments. The emotional beats, while well-constructed, don't achieve the depth that would elevate this from solid execution to exceptional writing. The chapter feels somewhat predictable in its progression, following expected romance beats without surprising insights or particularly fresh takes on familiar situations. The character consistency is excellent—both Rhys and Ellis behave exactly as their profiles suggest, with Ellis's defensive guardedness gradually softening and Rhys oscillating between performed charm and genuine vulnerability. The author maintains the established power dynamic where Ellis's disinterest paradoxically increases Rhys's genuine interest. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 11 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 4: The Anchor The Anchor was warm and loud, wood smoke and bodies and the football on in the corner. Ellis was halfway through a mediocre lasagna when Rhys walked in. Their stomach did something inconvenient. Rhys saw them, stopped, started to back toward the door. Ellis raised a hand before they'd decided to. Rhys hesitated, then came over. "Hi. Sorry, I didn't know you'd be—I can sit somewhere else." "Don't be daft." Meredith smiled up at him. "Join us." Ellis had been planning to end things with Meredith tonight. Had rehearsed it during the afternoon lull. Now they sat mute while Meredith pulled over a chair. "Meredith," she said, offering her hand. "I know who you are. I loved *The Cartographer's Daughter*." Rhys's face did the thing—shifted into something public. "Oh, thank you! That's very kind. That was a lovely project, we shot in—" "Morocco, right? It looked stunning." "Parts of it. Some was actually Almería, Spain. Much cheaper." He laughed. The actor laugh, Ellis recognized now. Practiced. "What do you do?" "Marine biology. Seals, mostly. Less glamorous than Morocco." "Are you kidding? That's fascinating. I did a thing once where I had to—well, this is boring, sorry." "No, go on." And he did. Rhys told a story about learning to sail for a role, getting seasick, the director being furious. He was good at it—paced it well, self-deprecating in a way that invited contradiction. Meredith laughed. Others at nearby tables glanced over, recognition dawning. Ellis ate their lasagna and watched him perform. Meredith's phone buzzed. She glanced at it, frowned. "Shit. Sorry, there's a seal pup beached near Broadhaven. I have to—" She was already standing, grabbing her coat. "Ellis, I'll call you tomorrow? Rhys, lovely to meet you." She kissed Ellis's cheek—too familiar, too presumptive—and was gone. The silence felt loud. "Sorry," Rhys said. "I didn't mean to—is that your—" "It's casual." "Right. Casual." He flagged down Siân from behind the bar. "Can I get a pint? And whatever Ellis is drinking." "Wine. Red." "Wine, please." Siân brought the drinks, gave Ellis a significant look, and retreated. Ellis would hear about this later. "You do that a lot," Ellis said. "What?" "Become someone else when people know who you are." Rhys's hand stopped halfway to his pint. "I don't—" "The sailing story. You tell it well. Too well. Like you've told it before." "I have told it before. It's a good story." "Is it true?" "Of course it's—" He stopped. Drank. "Mostly. The essentials are true. I might have... polished it." "You were different this morning. In the shop." "Was I?" Ellis didn't answer. They both knew. Rhys turned his glass in his hands. "It's easier," he said finally. "When people know you, or think they do, it's easier to just... give them what they expect. The stories, the charm, the whole—otherwise they're disappointed." "That sounds exhausting." "It is." He drank again, too fast. "But the alternative is worse." "Which is?" "Being boring. Being just... some bloke who doesn't have anything interesting to say." Ellis looked at him. Saw the need underneath. "You think you're boring?" "I think I might be, yeah. Without the stories, without the—what am I? Just someone who says other people's words for money." "That's acting." "Is it?" Rhys ordered another pint. Ellis didn't stop him. "Sometimes I think I've been performing so long I don't know what's real anymore. I go home to my flat in London and I don't know who lives there. You know?" Ellis did know. They ordered another wine. An hour passed, then another. The pub thinned out. They talked about London—Ellis's version, Rhys's version, two different cities. Rhys told real stories now, not polished ones. About being lonely at premieres. About his ex, Gemma, who he couldn't quite let go of. About loving acting and hating everything around it. Ellis talked about the panic attacks. The morning they couldn't get on the tube. The sick leave that became resignation. Coming to Wales like running away, which it was. "So we're both hiding," Rhys said. "I'm not hiding." "No?" "I'm building something. That's different." "Is it working?" Ellis didn't answer. Drank instead. At closing, Siân ushered them out with knowing amusement. The air outside was sharp, cold, salt-thick. The coastal path back to the bookshop wound along the cliffs. They walked close together against the wind. Rhys stumbled once, caught Ellis's arm. Didn't let go immediately. "Thanks for tonight," he said. "For—I don't know. Listening." "You talk a lot." "I know. Sorry." "I didn't say it was bad." They stopped at the corner where the path split—one way to the bookshop, one toward the newer houses where Rhys's mum lived. Street light made Rhys's face half-shadow. He was looking at Ellis's mouth. "This is a bad idea," Ellis said. "What is?" "Whatever you're thinking about doing." "How do you know what I'm thinking?" "Rhys." He stepped closer. Ellis could smell wine and wool and something underneath, just him. "Why is it a bad idea?" "You're leaving." "Not yet." "Soon." "Does that matter?" It should. Ellis knew it should. But Rhys was very close now, and they'd spent three days noticing his hands, his mouth, the way he moved. Spent tonight watching him peel away the performance. Ellis stepped back. "I should—it's late." Disappointment crossed Rhys's face, chased quickly by understanding. "Right. Yeah. Of course." "Goodnight, Rhys." "Night." Ellis walked away feeling his eyes on their back. At the bookshop door, they turned. Rhys was still standing there, hands in pockets, watching. He raised one hand. Ellis went inside. Upstairs in the flat, they didn't turn on the lights. Stood at the window and watched Rhys finally walk away, disappearing into the dark. Tolstoy wound around their ankles, complaining. "I know," Ellis said. "Stupid." The cat had no sympathy.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively continues the slow-burn romance between Rhys and Ellis, delivering on both the author's chapter plan and the original prompt's requirements. The writing demonstrates strong character work and naturalistic dialogue, though it operates within fairly conventional romantic beats. The chapter's greatest strength lies in its nuanced portrayal of performance versus authenticity. The author skillfully shows Rhys shifting into "celebrity mode" when Meredith recognizes him, then contrasts this with his more vulnerable behavior once they're alone. Ellis's observation - "You do that a lot... Become someone else when people know who you are" - feels earned rather than forced, and Rhys's defensive then honest response rings true to his established character. The dialogue maintains distinct voices throughout. Rhys's tendency toward practiced anecdotes ("The sailing story. You tell it well. Too well. Like you've told it before") versus his more halting admissions of loneliness feels authentic. Ellis's economical, slightly sharp observations ("That sounds exhausting") effectively contrast with Rhys's more expansive speech patterns. Character consistency is strong. Rhys's fragile ego shows through his fear of being "boring," while Ellis's guardedness manifests in their quick retreat from physical intimacy. Both characters' backstories inform their present behavior without feeling overly explanatory. The emotional progression feels natural - alcohol loosening inhibitions, shared vulnerabilities creating intimacy, physical attraction building to an almost-kiss that gets interrupted by Ellis's self-protective instincts. The "This is a bad idea" / "You're leaving" exchange effectively establishes the central conflict without belaboring it. However, the chapter operates within fairly predictable romantic beats: third wheel conveniently called away, bonding conversation over drinks, walk in atmospheric weather, almost-kiss interrupted by practical concerns. While executed competently, these moments lack surprising turns or deeper emotional complexity. The prose remains clean and unadorned, avoiding purple passages while still creating atmosphere ("salt-thick air," "half-shadow"). The pacing moves smoothly between public performance and private vulnerability. Minor weaknesses include some functional but unremarkable transitions and a few moments where deeper emotional excavation might have elevated the scene. The Meredith subplot feels somewhat perfunctory, serving plot mechanics more than character development. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 5: Shipping Ellis sent the text before they could overthink it. *I think we should stop this. You're lovely, but I'm not in the right place. Sorry. E* Meredith's reply came ten minutes later: *Honestly relieved. You're a bit too much in your head for me. Still friends? x* *Yes. Good luck with the seals.* *Good luck with the actor.* Ellis put the phone face-down and made tea they didn't want. --- Rhys's mum was in the garden, deadheading roses that should have been done weeks ago. "You're up early," she said, not looking at him. "Couldn't sleep." "Your phone was going off at all hours. Heard it through the wall." Gemma had texted at 2am. Then 3am. Photos from some party, inside jokes, *miss your face*. He'd replied to the last one. Shouldn't have, but had. "Sorry, Mam. I'll put it on silent." "That bookshop person," she said, snapping off a dead bloom. "The one who bought the Morgans' old place above the shop. You've been spending time there." Not a question. Pennaeth was small. "Just visiting. Looking at books." "Hmm." She straightened, rubbed her back. "Mrs. Parry said you're helping with stock." "I unpacked some boxes." "And you went to the Anchor." "Mam—" "I'm not saying anything." She looked at him now, squinting in the weak sun. "You're only here another week." "I know." "Do you?" He didn't know how to answer that. Went inside and made tea he didn't drink. --- The shop was quiet when Rhys arrived at noon. Ellis was at the counter, reading. They looked up, and something in their face was different. Less guarded. "Hi." "Hi." Rhys felt suddenly nervous. "I brought—I didn't bring anything. I should have brought something." "You don't have to bring things." "I keep bringing chips." "I've noticed." They looked at each other. Ellis closed their book. "Do you want to go somewhere?" Ellis asked. "I can close for an hour." "Yeah. Yes. Where?" "Beach?" --- It wasn't romantic. The sky was grey, the wind sharp, the sand cold and ridged from yesterday's tide. They walked along the waterline, hands in pockets. "Meredith and I aren't—we're not seeing each other anymore," Ellis said. "Oh. I'm sorry." "Don't be. It wasn't... it was running out anyway." Rhys nodded. Didn't ask why they were telling him. They walked in silence. A dog ran past, manic with joy. Its owner nodded at them. "I don't think I like my life," Rhys said. Ellis glanced at him. "That sounds—I know how that sounds. Poor rich actor, living his dream. But I don't know if it is. My dream. Or if it was and now it's just... what I do." "What would you do instead?" "I don't know. That's the problem, isn't it? I've been doing this for fifteen years. It's all I know." Ellis stopped walking. Looked out at the water. "I thought moving here would fix things. The anxiety, the—everything. And it helped, it did. But I'm still..." They trailed off. "Still what?" "Scared. All the time. That I made a mistake. That the shop will fail. That I'm just hiding." "You said you weren't hiding." "I lied." Rhys laughed. Couldn't help it. Ellis smiled, small and real. "We're a pair, aren't we?" Rhys said. "Seems like it." They started walking again, closer now. Their shoulders bumped. "How long are you here?" Ellis asked. "Mam's birthday is Saturday. I fly back Sunday morning." "Five days." "Yeah." "Then what?" "Then I go back to my flat and wait for my agent to call with the next thing. Audition or meeting or—something. I don't have anything lined up right now." "How does that feel?" "Terrifying. Freeing. Both." They'd reached the rocks at the end of the beach. Ellis sat, legs dangling. Rhys sat beside them. Close enough to feel warmth. "I keep thinking about your hands," Ellis said, not looking at him. Rhys's brain stuttered. "What?" "Since you walked in three days ago. I keep noticing your hands." Ellis's face was going red. "It's annoying." "Annoying?" "Very." Rhys looked at his hands. They seemed unremarkable. "Why?" "I don't know. They just—" Ellis finally looked at him. "This is stupid." "What is?" "You're leaving in five days." "I know." "So this is—whatever this is—it's stupid." "Probably." Ellis's eyes dropped to his mouth. Rhys stopped breathing. "Fuck it," Ellis said, and kissed him. It was awkward—angles wrong, teeth clicking, too much urgency. Then Rhys's hand found Ellis's jaw and Ellis's fingers curled into his jacket and it was good, it was— Ellis pulled back. "You're still leaving." "I know." Rhys's heart was hammering. "I know, but—" "Come back to the shop." "Okay." "I mean—" Ellis stood abruptly. "Upstairs. Come upstairs." "Oh." Rhys stood too. "Yes. Okay. Yes." They walked back fast, not talking. The shop was still closed, sign still flipped. Ellis's hands shook unlocking the door. Upstairs, the flat was small and cold. Unmade bed, books everywhere, a hostile cat that fled immediately. "Sorry, it's—" Rhys kissed them. Softer this time. Ellis made a sound and pulled him toward the bed. Afterward, lying in the dim afternoon light, Rhys traced the line of Ellis's shoulder. "I don't know what this is," Ellis said quietly. "Neither do I." "You're still leaving Sunday." "I know." Ellis turned to face him. "I'm not good at this. At—people." "You're doing fine." "I'm really not." Rhys kissed their forehead. "Neither am I." Outside, rain started. The cat returned, judging them from the doorway. Ellis laughed, breathless and uncertain. "Well," they said. "Now what?" Rhys had no answer. Kissed them instead.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively advances the central romance while maintaining the established character dynamics. The writing demonstrates strong craft in several areas, particularly in dialogue and character consistency. The structure works well, moving from morning resolution (Ellis ending things with Meredith) through family pressure (Rhys dealing with his mother's awareness) to intimate connection. The beach scene serves as an effective emotional pivot, allowing both characters to express vulnerability without melodrama. Ellis's admission "I lied" about not hiding, and Rhys's confession about not liking his life, feel authentic and earned. The dialogue maintains distinct voices throughout. Ellis's characteristic directness ("This is stupid," "I keep thinking about your hands") contrasts effectively with Rhys's more nervous, rambling style. The conversation flows naturally, with realistic interruptions and half-finished thoughts. The sexual tension builds organically through small admissions and physical awareness. Character consistency is strong. Ellis's conflict avoidance appears in how they handle ending things with Meredith via text, while their directness emerges in the beach conversation. Rhys's people-pleasing nature shows in his interaction with his mother, while his genuine confusion about his life choices feels consistent with his established fragility. The prose remains clean and functional without excessive ornamentation. Physical details ground the scenes effectively - the cold beach, the hostile cat, Ellis's shaking hands - without overwhelming the emotional content. The pacing builds appropriately toward the physical intimacy. However, the chapter diverges somewhat from its stated plan, which anticipated a "morning after" scenario. Instead, this depicts their first intimate encounter. While the emotional beats align with the plan, the timeline doesn't match exactly. The writing avoids common romance pitfalls - the physical connection feels awkward initially then natural, rather than impossibly perfect. The acknowledgment that "this is stupid" because Rhys is leaving adds realistic tension without artificial drama. Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: Morning The flat was freezing. Ellis woke to grey light and Rhys's phone buzzing on the floor. "Sorry," Rhys mumbled, not moving. "I'll turn it off." He didn't. It buzzed again. And again. Ellis extracted themself from the tangle of limbs and duvet, grabbed their dressing gown from the door. Downstairs the shop was dim and quiet. They flipped the sign to Open without much hope anyone would come. When they came back up with tea, Rhys was sitting on the edge of the bed, looking at his phone. His face was different. Actor face. "Everything okay?" "Yeah. Just—my agent. And my publicist. And Gemma." He looked up, saw Ellis's expression. "My ex. She's just—we're friends. Sort of." "Right." "It's not—we're not—" "You don't have to explain." But the warmth from earlier had leaked away. Ellis handed him tea and went to shower. When they came back, dressed, Rhys was still in just his jeans, texting. He looked up guiltily. "Sorry. Just dealing with—sorry." "It's fine." It wasn't, quite. But Ellis didn't know what claim they had. One night. Less than one night. "Have you got eggs?" Rhys asked. "I could make—I'm actually a decent cook." "I've got bread." "Toast it is." They assembled breakfast from Ellis's meager supplies: toast, butter, the end of some jam. Ate standing at the kitchen counter because the flat didn't have a table. "This place is freezing," Rhys said. "Heating's broken." "How long?" "Few weeks." "Ellis. It's almost November." "I know." "You should get it fixed." "I will." Rhys looked like he wanted to say more, but didn't. His phone buzzed again. He ignored it. "I fly back Sunday," he said. "You mentioned." "Four days." Ellis bit into toast. It tasted like cardboard. "What happens then?" "I don't know. Auditions. Meetings. My agent wants me to read for this franchise thing. Big budget, terrible script, three films if the first one works." "Will you do it?" "Probably. It's—the money's stupid. And it would be... steady work." "You don't sound excited." "I'm not. But that's the job." He drank his tea. "What about you? What happens after Sunday?" "Same as before. Shop. Books. Trying not to go bankrupt." "Is it that bad?" Ellis shrugged. Didn't want to talk about the numbers, the dwindling inheritance, the spreadsheet of doom. Rhys's phone rang. Properly rang, not just buzzed. He looked at it, swore softly. "I have to—sorry. Just give me two minutes." He went into the other room. Ellis heard his voice change, brighten. "Matt, hi, yeah, I got your messages..." Then lower, walking further away. Ellis washed the plates. The water was barely warm. Another thing to deal with. When Rhys came back, he was smiling the wrong smile. "Sorry. That was—he wants me to do this Q&A thing next week, and a podcast, and there's a premiere in December I said I'd go to, so..." He trailed off. "Sorry." "Stop apologizing." "I'm—" He stopped. Laughed. "Yeah. Sorry. Fuck." Downstairs, the bell cracked. Ellis went down. Rhys followed, pulling on his jumper from yesterday. Two people in their twenties, clearly tourists, browsing. The woman did a double-take when she saw Rhys. "Oh my God," she whispered to her boyfriend. Not quietly enough. Rhys's posture changed. Ready. "Excuse me," the woman approached. "Are you—sorry, this is so rude—but are you Rhys Morgan?" "I am, yeah." Smile. The right one now. "How are you?" "We loved you in *The Cartographer's Daughter*! Could we—would you mind a photo?" "Of course, no problem." Ellis watched from behind the counter. Watched Rhys position himself, arm around the woman's shoulders, find his light. The boyfriend took three photos. Then Rhys took one with the boyfriend. Then a selfie with both of them. "Are you here filming something?" the woman asked. "Just visiting. Hometown." "That's so nice! Do you come back often?" "When I can." Lies, Ellis thought. Or polished truth. Same thing. The couple left without buying anything. The shop felt smaller. "Sorry," Rhys said. "Stop—" "—saying sorry, I know." He ran his hand through his hair. "Is that... does that bother you?" "I don't know yet." Honest, at least. They worked in the shop. Rhys was quieter, kept checking his phone. Ellis felt him slipping away, back into his other life. Tried not to mind. Around three, Gareth came in for the new Sarah Waters. Nodded at Rhys. "Alright?" "Yeah, good." "Heard you were about." Gareth looked at Ellis. "You coming to quiz night Thursday?" "Maybe." "Bring your friend. We could use the help." He paid for his book, left. After he'd gone, Rhys said, "He was... normal." "Gareth doesn't care about celebrities. He cares about quiz night." "That's refreshing." "This is a good place," Ellis said. "The people here. They've been—when I first moved, I was a mess. Couldn't talk to people. Siân kept coming into the shop, just chatting until I could chat back. Mrs. Parry brought me soup when I had flu. Gareth fixed my car that time. They're good." Rhys was quiet. "You've built something here." "Trying to." "And I'm—" He gestured vaguely. "Disrupting it." "A bit." "Sorry." Ellis almost smiled. "What did I say about apologizing?" That evening they made pasta in Ellis's inadequate kitchen. Rhys chopped vegetables with surprising competence. They ate on the sofa, the cat finally deigning to investigate Rhys. "I want more time," Rhys said. "You don't have it." "I know." The cat climbed onto Rhys's lap, shocking them both. "Tolstoy likes you," Ellis said. "He doesn't like anyone." "I feel very honored." Rhys scratched behind the cat's ears. "What if—" "Don't." "Don't what?" "Say something about long distance or visiting or trying. We've known each other less than a week." "Feels longer." It did. That was the problem. They went to bed early, both pretending it was just tiredness. Made love slower this time, careful. Ellis felt like they were memorizing something. After, Rhys's phone lit up on the floor. He ignored it. Pulled Ellis closer. "Four days," he said into the dark. Ellis didn't answer. Outside, the sea was loud against the rocks.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully delivers a realistic "morning after" that avoids both saccharine romance clichés and melodramatic conflict. The writing demonstrates strong character work, particularly in showing how Rhys's two worlds—his genuine connection with Ellis and his celebrity obligations—begin to collide and create tension. The opening sequence effectively establishes mood through concrete details: the freezing flat, the buzzing phone, Ellis's meager breakfast supplies. These details serve dual purposes, both advancing plot and revealing character—Ellis's financial struggles (broken heating, sparse groceries) and Rhys's inability to disconnect from his professional life. The dialogue feels authentic and character-specific. Ellis's economy of speech ("Right." "I will.") contrasts well with Rhys's tendency to over-explain and apologize. The conversation about logistics is handled with appropriate awkwardness—neither character quite knows what they're doing, which feels honest. The tourist photo sequence is particularly well-executed. Rather than being melodramatic, it simply shows the reality of Rhys's life intruding. The detail of them buying nothing after the photos adds a subtle layer of irony. Rhys's transformation into "actor mode" is shown rather than told, and Ellis's observation of this shift feels natural. The Gareth interaction works well to establish Ellis's connection to their community and Rhys's position as an outsider, though this could have been pushed further. The chapter maintains good pacing throughout, moving from morning intimacy through daily interactions to evening reflection. The ending conversation ("I want more time" / "You don't have it") cuts to the heart of their dilemma without being overly dramatic. The final image of them in bed with the sea audible outside provides appropriate atmosphere without becoming purple. Some weaknesses: The chapter occasionally relies on summary rather than scene (the shower sequence, some transitions), and certain moments could benefit from more specific sensory detail. The cat appearance feels slightly convenient for character revelation. Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: Famous Wednesday morning, Rhys's phone started at seven. Ellis felt him ease out of bed, heard him in the other room, voice low. They lay there, staring at the ceiling, Tolstoy heavy on their feet. When Rhys came back, he looked tired. "Reshoots. For the period thing I did last spring. They need me in LA Friday." Ellis sat up. "This Friday?" "Yeah. I can probably push it to Saturday, but—" "That's two days." "I know." "You said Sunday." "I thought it was. But they've got the crew, the location, and if I don't—" He stopped. "I have to go, Ellis." "I know you do." But something hardened in Ellis's chest. Of course he did. This was always temporary. Rhys reached for them. Ellis let themselves be pulled in, but didn't quite soften into it. --- The shop felt different with both of them in it now. Like playing house. Mrs. Parry came in, bought nothing, told Rhys how much his mam must love having him home. A teenager asked for a photo. An older man wanted to discuss Rhys's performance in something from five years ago. Ellis shelved books and watched it happen. Watched Rhys be gracious, patient, performed. "Does it ever stop?" they asked when they were alone. "What?" "That. People wanting pieces of you." "Not really." Rhys was looking at his phone again. "Sorry, I just—my publicist needs me to approve some posts, and there's this thing about—sorry." "You're on your phone more than you're here." Rhys looked up. "That's not fair." "Isn't it?" "I'm trying to manage two lives at once." "That's the problem." Rhys set his phone down, carefully. "What do you want me to do, Ellis? This is my job." "I know." "So—" "So nothing. I'm not—" Ellis turned away. "Forget it." But they couldn't. The phone kept buzzing. Rhys kept checking it. The world kept intruding. --- At lunch, Siân came in with sandwiches neither of them had ordered. "You two look miserable," she said. "Eat." "We're fine," Ellis said. "Right. That's why you're both moping around like wet cats." She leaned against the counter. "You know the whole town's talking about you?" "Christ," Rhys muttered. "Not bad talk. Just talk. Eirlys is pleased. She told Mrs. Davies you're being good company for Ellis." Ellis felt their face heat. "Siân—" "I'm just saying. Small town. Everyone knows everything." She headed for the door. "And Rhys? Someone posted a photo from the Anchor on Twitter. Might want to check that." When she'd gone, Rhys pulled out his phone. His face went carefully blank. "What is it?" He turned the screen. A tabloid site: *Rhys Morgan's Secret Welsh Romance?* Below it, a photo of them walking back from the beach. Not touching, but close. The caption speculated about "mystery companion." Ellis felt sick. "I'm sorry," Rhys said. "I didn't know anyone—" "Is this what it's like?" Ellis asked. "People taking photos without asking? Writing about you?" "Sometimes. Usually it's—this is mild, actually." "Mild." "Ellis—" "I moved here to get away from being watched. From anxiety about being perceived. And now—" They gestured at the phone. "It's one photo. It'll blow over." "Will it?" Rhys didn't answer. Ellis went upstairs. Heard Rhys on the phone in the shop below, his voice tight. Dealing with it. Managing it. They lay on the bed and stared at the ceiling. --- Evening, Rhys came up. Sat on the edge of the bed. "My publicist says it's fine. It'll be gone by tomorrow. Some footballer did something stupid, it's already pushing me off the homepage." "How comforting." "Ellis—" "Is this what it would be like? If we—" Ellis couldn't finish. If we what? Tried? They'd known each other six days. "I don't know," Rhys said. "Maybe. Sometimes. Or maybe you'd hate it and I'd resent you for hating it and we'd fall apart anyway." "Very romantic." "I'm trying to be honest." Ellis sat up. "You're leaving Friday. Saturday if you're lucky. I'm here. I'll always be here because I can't—I can't do that." They gestured vaguely toward the world beyond. "The exposure, the travel, the performing. I can barely manage this." They meant the shop, the town, their small careful life. "I'm not asking you to." "Aren't you?" "No. I don't—" Rhys stood, paced. "I don't know what I'm asking. I don't know what this is." "It's a week." "It feels like more." "It's not." Rhys turned. "You don't feel it?" Ellis did. That was the problem. "What I feel doesn't matter. The facts are: you leave. I stay. We live completely different lives. And one photo in a tabloid makes me want to hide for a week." "So that's it?" "What else is there?" Rhys looked at them for a long moment. Then sat back down, deflated. "I don't know." They sat in silence. Tolstoy jumped up, settled between them like a mediator. "I wish I'd met you differently," Rhys said finally. "Somewhere else. Some other time." "But you didn't." "No." Ellis reached for his hand. Held it. "We've got tomorrow." "One day." "Better than none." Rhys's phone buzzed. He ignored it. It buzzed again. "You should check that," Ellis said. "I don't want to." "Rhys." He checked it. Whatever it was made his jaw tighten. "My agent. The franchise thing. They want an answer by Friday." "What will you say?" "I don't know." He looked at Ellis. "What do you think I should say?" "It's not my decision." "But if it was?" Ellis pulled their hand back. "Don't do that. Don't make me responsible for your choices." "That's not what I'm—" "It is." Ellis stood. "You want me to tell you to stay, or to go, or to take the job, or not. And then if it goes wrong, it's not your fault." "That's not fair." "Isn't it?" Rhys's face shuttered. "I should go back to my mam's." "Probably." He gathered his things. At the door, he stopped. "Tomorrow?" "I'll be here." "Ellis—" "Goodnight, Rhys." When he'd gone, the flat felt enormous and empty. Ellis poured wine, drank it too fast. Poured more. Their phone buzzed. Meredith: *Saw the article. You ok?* No, Ellis thought. But they typed: *Fine.* Outside, rain started. Ellis stood at the window, watching the street blur. Somewhere out there, Rhys was walking back to his mother's, to his other life. In two days he'd be gone. Ellis drank more wine and tried to convince themselves they didn't care.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers on the romance premise while introducing realistic relationship tension. The writing demonstrates strong character consistency, with both Rhys and Ellis behaving exactly as established in their profiles. Rhys's constant phone usage and celebrity obligations create authentic conflict, while Ellis's withdrawal feels psychologically accurate given their established need for privacy and control. The dialogue captures distinct voices well - Ellis's terse responses ("I know you do," "Isn't it?") versus Rhys's more elaborate explanations. The conflict builds naturally through concrete details like the buzzing phone and tabloid photo rather than manufactured drama. The author avoids romance clichés by showing how incompatible lifestyles create genuine obstacles beyond simple misunderstandings. Structurally, the chapter follows its planned trajectory effectively, moving from morning tension through the tabloid revelation to evening confrontation. The prose remains clean and functional without purple flourishes, letting character dynamics drive the narrative. However, some dialogue exchanges feel repetitive, particularly the frequent use of "I know." Certain emotional moments could be pushed deeper - the tabloid revelation feels somewhat underplayed given Ellis's established anxiety about exposure. Some scenes end just before reaching their emotional core, which occasionally leaves beats feeling incomplete. The chapter successfully maintains the established tone of realistic messiness rather than idealized romance. The conflict feels earned and inevitable given the characters' circumstances, avoiding easy resolutions while maintaining reader investment in the relationship's outcome. Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: The Longhand Thursday morning, Ellis opened the shop and tried to pretend everything was normal. It wasn't. The bell cracked and they jumped. Just a delivery. They signed for it, stacked the boxes without opening them. Rhys didn't come. At eleven, Mrs. Davies came in, moving slowly, browsing the Local History section. "Looking for anything specific?" Ellis asked. "Just browsing, love." She pulled out a book on Pembrokeshire folklore, put it back. "Rhys gone back then?" "Tomorrow. Or Saturday." "Hmm." She moved to Fiction. "He was a funny boy." "Sorry?" "When he was young. Always performing, always on. School plays, eisteddfods, showing off." She smiled. "But sometimes you'd catch him just sitting, reading in the corner of the library. Completely still. Like he'd forgotten to be noticed." Ellis said nothing. "He wanted to be a writer, you know. Before all the acting. Used to write these stories, fantasy things, quite good apparently. His English teacher tried to encourage it, but his parents..." She shrugged. "Wanted something practical. Acting seemed more practical than writing, I suppose." "I didn't know that." "No, well. Long time ago now." Mrs. Davies picked up a Barbara Pym. "This one's good, is it?" "If you like quiet observation." "I do." She bought it. Actually bought it. At the door, she paused. "He's always running, that boy. Don't know if he's running toward something or away from it. Maybe he doesn't either." When she'd gone, Ellis stood in the empty shop, thinking. --- Rhys sat in his childhood bedroom, staring at his phone. The franchise contract was open on the screen. Three films, minimum. Two years of his life, probably more. Financial security. Steady work. The kind of thing that made you unavailable for anything else. His mam knocked, came in without waiting. "You're moping." "I'm thinking." "You've been thinking for two days. Think downstairs. I made bara brith." He followed her down. The kitchen smelled like childhood—tea, baking, the specific warmth of this house. "When are you going?" she asked, cutting thick slices. "Tomorrow. Maybe Saturday if I can push it." "And then?" "LA for a week. Then London. Then... I don't know." She put tea in front of him. Proper tea, in her good cups. "What about the bookshop person?" "Ellis." "Ellis, then." "What about them?" "Don't be thick, Rhys. You're clearly—" She waved her hand. "Whatever you are." "It's complicated." "Always is." She sat across from him. "You know what your problem is?" "I'm sure you'll tell me." "You think everything has to be one thing or another. Acting or writing. London or here. Famous or normal. You never could just... be in the middle of things." "There is no middle with this, Mam. My life is there. Ellis's is here." "So change your life." "It's not that simple." "Isn't it?" She sipped her tea. "You're always saying you're so unhappy. So be different." "And do what?" "I don't know, cariad. But running back and forth isn't working, is it?" --- At four, the bell cracked. Ellis looked up. Rhys stood in the doorway, uncertain. "Hi." "Hi." "Can I—can we talk?" Ellis nodded. Locked the door, flipped the sign. They went upstairs. In the flat, Rhys paced. Ellis waited. "I don't know what I'm doing," Rhys said finally. "With work, with my life, with... this." "That's honest." "I keep thinking I should have answers. Should know what I want. But I don't." He stopped pacing. "The franchise thing. It's stupid money. Stupid opportunity. And I don't want it." "So don't take it." "But what if I'm just... running away from success? What if I'm self-sabotaging because I'm scared?" "Are you?" "I don't know!" He laughed, helpless. "See? No answers." Ellis stood, went to him. "What do you want, Rhys? Actually want, not what you should want." Rhys looked at them. "Time. I want time to figure things out. Time to—" He gestured between them. "This. Whatever this is. I want to read again. I want to not check my phone every five minutes. I want to wake up and not feel like I'm already behind." "So take time." "I can't just—people depend on me. My agent, the jobs, the—" "Do you want permission?" Ellis asked. "Because I can't give you that." "I know." They stood close, not touching. "I'm going to do the reshoots," Rhys said. "I have to. But the franchise... I'm going to say no." "Are you sure?" "No. But I'm doing it anyway." He reached for Ellis's hand. "And then I'm coming back. If that's—if you want me to." Ellis's heart did something painful. "For how long?" "I don't know. A week? Two? However long it takes to figure out if this is..." He trailed off. "If this is what?" "Real. Worth trying. Something." Ellis wanted to say yes immediately. Wanted to protect themselves and say no. Did neither. "I can't promise anything," they said. "I'm not asking you to." "I'm still going to be anxious about photos and exposure and all of it." "I know." "And you're still going to be on your phone too much and tell stories that are too polished and need everyone to like you." "Probably." "And it might not work." "It might not." Ellis looked at him. At this man who'd stumbled into their shop six days ago and somehow become... something. Someone. "Come back, then," Ellis said. "And we'll see." Rhys's smile was real. Uncertain, but real. "Yeah?" "Yeah." He kissed them. Soft, careful. Like a promise neither of them knew if they could keep. --- Friday morning, early, Rhys's taxi idled outside. They stood at the shop door. Ellis in their fingerless gloves and cardigan, Rhys in his expensive coat. "Two weeks," Rhys said. "Maybe three. I'll text you." "Okay." "And we'll—we'll figure it out." "Maybe." "Very reassuring." Ellis almost smiled. "I'm not going to make this easy for you." "I noticed." The taxi beeped. Rhys picked up his bag, put it down again. "I'm terrified this is stupid." "It probably is." "But you'll—when I come back—" "I'll be here," Ellis said. "Running my failing bookshop, drinking too much wine, hiding from the world." "Sounds perfect." "It's really not." Rhys kissed them once more. Got in the taxi. Ellis watched it disappear down the road, toward the station, toward his other life. Tolstoy wound around their ankles. "Well," Ellis said to the cat. "That was something." Inside, the shop was cold and quiet. They made tea, opened the boxes from yesterday's delivery. Put books on shelves. Waited for customers who might not come. Their phone buzzed. *Made the train. Already miss your terrible flat. -R* Ellis typed: *It's not that terrible.* *It absolutely is.* *Are you going to actually buy something next time, or just loiter?* A pause. Then: *We'll see about that.* Ellis smiled despite themselves. Put the phone down. Picked up their book. The bell would crack when the next customer came. Or it wouldn't. The heating would get fixed. Or it wouldn't. Rhys would come back. Or he wouldn't. Outside, rain started. Inside, Ellis read, and drank tea, and waited to see what happened next. The shop creaked and settled around them. Still here. Still trying. It would have to be enough.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter serves as the conclusion to what appears to be a romance story following the established prompt. The writing demonstrates several notable strengths while exhibiting some areas that could be stronger. The character work is generally solid. Ellis and Rhys maintain their established personalities - Ellis remains guarded and indirect ("Maybe" rather than "Yes"), while Rhys continues his pattern of self-doubt mixed with charm. The dialogue captures their distinct voices well, particularly Ellis's economy of words contrasting with Rhys's tendency to over-explain. Mrs. Davies serves as an effective vehicle for backstory about Rhys, though her appearance feels somewhat convenient as an exposition device. The emotional core of the chapter works effectively. The uncertainty both characters feel about their future together rings true, and the author resists the temptation to provide easy answers. The conversation where Rhys admits he doesn't know what he's doing feels authentic, as does Ellis's hesitant agreement to see what happens when he returns. The plot progression follows the established chapter plan reasonably well, moving from separation anxiety through honest conversation to tentative resolution. However, the pacing feels somewhat compressed for such significant emotional territory. The chapter covers major decisions (Rhys turning down the franchise, deciding to return) quite quickly. The writing style is generally clean and unadorned, which suits the realistic tone. However, some moments lack the specificity that would make them more vivid. The taxi scene, for instance, could benefit from more concrete detail to ground the emotional moment. The Welsh setting continues to feel authentic without being heavy-handed, and the supporting characters (particularly Rhys's mother) feel like real people rather than plot devices. The ending appropriately maintains uncertainty while providing enough hope to satisfy readers, staying true to the story's commitment to realism over easy resolution.
